summary: Fueled by his restored faith in humanity and inspired by Superman's selfless act, Bruce Wayne enlists newfound ally Diana Prince to face an even greater threat. Together, Batman and Wonder Woman work quickly to recruit a team to stand against this newly awakened enemy. Despite the formation of an unprecedented league of heroes -- Batman, Wonder Woman, Aquaman, Cyborg and the Flash -- it may be too late to save the planet from an assault of catastrophic proportions.

The Justice League movie had some exciting action sequences and impressive special effects, but unfortunately, the weak plot and underdeveloped characters left me feeling disappointed. While it's always great to see superheroes come together to save the world, this movie lacked the depth and emotional resonance that would have made it truly memorable. Overall, I'd say it's worth a watch if you're a fan of the genre, but don't expect anything groundbreaking.

This movie is bad, really bad. While I was watching "Justice League" I looked for any redeeming qualities, and they are hard to find. The dialogue is awful, with unnecessary attempts at humor. The CGI is poor, with Steppenwolf looking like a rough first draft of a final villain. The acting is mediocre, mostly from Gal Gadot ("Kal-El, no!).

Take all those elements and a disjointed storyline, and you get the disaster that is "Justice League". There were multiple times where I had to rewind the movie to see if I missed something, because the editing was so choppy.

With poor relationship building and an incoherent plot, "Justice League" is an incredible disappointment. In the end, this movie is just a bunch of indestructible people hitting each other until the credits finally roll.

Best Piece of Score: "Home"

Additional Note: When Bruce talks about the table for 6 (plus more), I got excited, and I don't know why. It was probably excitement for whatever James Gunn is going to do to revive the franchise.

It's been a while since I've been this let down by a superhero movie that was supposed to be a big grand experience but it undeniably wasn't! So much charm, excitement, and exhilaration was missing! There's a lot of controversy between the Justice League VS Zack Snyder's Justice League, and I'm here to settle the debate once and for all. Justice League is the far superior movie. I am a major cinephile. I have seen all of the good ones. I rarely have seen the bad ones. Let me tell you, Zack Snyder's Justice League is a bad one, and the Justice League is a good one. Why you ask? Easy, mostly because of the way they are and not because of the way they aren't. Let's get to the one thing everyone wants to talk about: The Joker, the clown prince of crime himself. I am particularly fond of the Joker, and he doesn't appear in either film. You're probably thinking, "Peter S, I saw him in the trailer for Zack Snyder's Justice League when he made the society meme." First, I hate memes. Second, that wasn't even in the movie. Well now you're probably thinking, "Woah, that's crazy, then he wasn't in the Justice League either, right? RIGHT?" Actually, he was. Not many people noticed, but he is in the background of 8 scenes in this movie. He actually has more on screen time then General Zod if you can believe it. You're probably thinking, "What?" and I would say, "Yep, it's true. He's there." Is this what makes the Justice League better than Zach Snyder's Justice League? Yes and no. It's only 1 part of the larger picture. Not many people know this but Warner Brothers made a real life ARG to coincide with the release of the Justice League. Not a single person figured it out, and Warner Brothers never admitted to doing it. In fact, when I questioned them about it, they said, "We didn't do that." Likely story. If you pause the movie at 58 minutes (there about, I don't want to give it away completely) then you will see the second part of the riddle. The first part was posted on twitter 58 days before the film released on the official Warner Bros twitter. What do we get if we solve it? I don't know. My facebook group the gaped crusaders has some ideas. How does this make Justice League better than Zack Snyder's Justice League? I'm glad you asked. Warner Brothers is saying, "Hey, you have to become Batman to figure it out." Me? As Batman? No way. I was essentially a member of the crew. I was in the Justice League. Zack Snyder may have started the film, but it was Warner Bros executives who decided to cast me as the Batman, Bruce Wayne, Bats, the Dark Knight, the Caped Crusader. I haven't felt this involved since I won a contest to do a stunt for Michael Chiklis in the Fantastic Four movie. I didn't get to meet any of the cast members and Chiklis wasn't on set that day and they didn't use the scene in the movie, but just being part of something bigger than myself made me feel strong.

Having been underwhelmed by the waste of great potential that was 'Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice' (not terrible but rather lacklustre) and seeing that critical reception was not particularly good, expectations for 'Justice League' were not very high.

Although it has major problems, 'Justice League' turned out to be better than expected. Contrary to the constant critic bashing, which to be perfectly honest has gotten out of control and extremely annoying fast for a while now, critics get a good deal of respect from me. Even when my opinions differ to theirs, which has happened a fair number of times, their appraisals and criticisms are very understandable and it is easy to see where they are coming from. 'Justice League' is a case of the film being much better than anticipated, considering the word of mouth and 'Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice' being so disappointing. Is 'Justice League' better than that film? Yes, by quite a bit.

'Justice League' does have its problems. Although the CGI is pretty good on the whole, there is an over-reliance of it and it doesn't always add to some of the scenes. The story has its fun and excitingly compelling moments, but a lot of it does feel rushed, which does see too many abrupt tonal and storytelling shifts, and some of the first half has a cobbled together and rambling quality. Am usually not one to carp about plot holes, much of the time it is a lazy criticism to me, but one can fit the Grand Canyon through some of them and some border on the ridiculous.

The rushed pacing does come at the expense of character development, which tends to be rather flimsy. Particularly true to this is the villain, there is nothing menacing or remotely interesting about him, he's basically a very dull just there sort of character. Ciaran Hinds is completely wasted, while Ray Fisher is somewhat dull. Not all the jokes work, some feel out of place, while the final battle could have had more excitement and Danny Elfman's music score is uninspired and forgettable.

On the other hand, most of the acting is very good. Ben Affleck brings a brooding intensity to Batman and he didn't seem that bored to me. Other bright spots in the cast are Jeremy Irons' very amusing Alfred, Amy Adams' feisty if somewhat underused Lois Lane, Jason Momoa's beautifully judged Aquaman and particularly Gal Gadot's positively show-stopping Wonder Woman. Ezra Miller is amusing, if at times slightly too introverted, as Flash and Henry Cavill looks much more comfortable here than he did in 'Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice'. Diane Lane and JK Simmons are also welcome presences.

Visually, 'Justice League' is beautifully shot, far more cohesively edited and its boldly dark and gritty look fits very well within the story. The script is less clunky and dreary and lightened by some nice quirky humour and some jokes are amusing, especially the absolute hoot that involves the magic lasso. The action is mostly nicely choreographed and fun to watch, some of the characters are interesting and the chemistry is great.

In summary, could have been much better but to me it wasn't that bad. 5.5-6/10 Bethany Cox

From the start - Ben Affleck as Batman is just a poor choice.  Given he's an improvement on the Kilmer and Clooney, and the script didn't help much either, I just can't recall a movie where I saw his range validating him as a choice here.  Now knowing that WB cast Pattison shows that they cannot make good choices for DC movies.  While Pattison is a better actor than Affleck, he doesn't look the part and carries an immediate stigmatism that DC can't afford after watching Justice League.  

Jason Momoa is not a bad choice for Aquaman and was fine for what the role allowed him, he can play more than just a big surfer.  Yet we we have a script that makes him sound like a drunken frat boy instead of the future king of Atlantis.  

Cyborg was just boring, I think I dozed off during the Synder cut with his extended screen time.  Ray Fischer was another poor choice to play the role - Cyborg was really made memorable in TT (not TT:Go), and "BOOYAH" has been said multiple times in the comics prior.  So Whedon and Fischer were probably not a proper pair to work together - but it again goes back to the original script being soo bad.

Ezra Miller is a bright spot in the movie - especially the Synder cut.  He is able to bring the serious and goofy Barry Allen to life.  Maybe a Flashpoint will erase all this and let us start anew with Miller's Flash being the focal point, and the more comical Wally West making an appearance!  

Special effects were typical, but half the movie is shot in a box format that doesn't match up with todays viewing preferences.  Let's change something else to an already over crowded, poorly scripted movie!  

With the theatrical release, we have Joss Whedon trying to reshoot parts from an entirely different bad script, and then force them into an originally script that was already poor and convoluted.  The Schneider cut was only marginally better because at least it's just one bad script with some better continuity, but it's still just boring and dull.  

I luckily saw the original release while flying and felt better about not paying.  After recently watching the Synder cut, I can say that I've seen it once, and don't need to see it again.  Better luck next time WB....

Ultimately though, the villain is the team themselves, and they do a great job of explaining that thoroughly.

The production drama behind Justice League is actually more well known than the movie itself. Wrought with a series of problems on and off the set, Justice League is a mess of a film. Director Zak Snyder had an original cut of the film, which at over 3 hours, was deemed by the studio ‘unwatchable'. He was dismissed before the film was completed; however, originally it was announced he has stepped down due to his daughter's death.  Warner Bros. brought in writer/director Joss Whedon to lighten the tone of the film, by shooting new scenes, changing the score, the colour grading and special effects, however the original cinematographer of Justice League has claimed only 10% of the original film remains in the theatrical cut. 

Due to the massive reshoots, the film's budget grew to $300 million USD, and became one of the most expensive films ever made. Unfortunately, due to the poor reviews and audience reception, the film made less than $700 million USD worldwide, which did not cover the costs of production and promotion, thus a sequel was scrapped. Since the film's release, fans have been hounding Warner Bros. to release Zak Snyder's original cut, even raising money to help with production costs, though the studio has stated they have no interest.

But getting back to the film, the final product is mostly a waste of money, sure the gathering of the team is interesting and the plot, though not great, is very much of the comics, however the visual effects are laughable at times, there are too many brooding ‘bro-ish' male leads on the team, and the only real upside could have been an even better sequel, which as I mentioned is now quashed.

Well, considering that Joss Whedon made extensive changes to this movie after Zack Snyder left the project, I'm pretty unimpressed by what we got in Justice League. This first big group movie for the DCEU brings together 6 superheroes, similarly to The Avengers, to help face a world ending threat. On the surface, with Joss Whedon working on it, that all seems like a great idea considering how good the first Avengers movie was. Unfortunately, when you look at the fine print, this film doesn't live up to any of those expectations and is a huge letdown in a lot of ways. The acting is decent but the movie doesn't make great use of it's A-list actors, which it has a fair amount of. The story is nothing new and the script is pretty lackluster and doesn't really give any characters moments to shine or do something memorable. The scenes aren't quite as bad as they were in Suicide Squad, but they only rise above them by a little bit and don't really earn redemption from the two terrible movies of 2016, Suicide Squad and Dawn of Justice. The dialogue is weird and awkward at times which makes the movie's attempts at humor feel iffy and come short and even a lot of the serious scenes don't work too well either. This movie doesn't flow smoothly in the way that The Avengers did, making it feel like a drag and be unenjoyable at times. The heroes themselves are a big problem. They are thinly written and given little backstory, so we don't learn too much about them, which is an issue because we've seen very little of some of them before the movie. Only half of the heroes had substantial appearances before the movie and they needed a lot more context and screentime to work and be effective in the movie. They feel underexplored both before and during the movie, which sucks because many of these characters are iconic and well known in the DC universe. So, we have missed opportunities there. The final fight of the movie makes Steppenwolf, the villain, feel really underwhelming and doesn't make him seem powerful enough to be a worthy adversary to the Justice League, which lowers the stakes of the movie a bit. The end of the movie is predictable and cliche and doesn't leave any surprises or twists waiting for us. My best description for this movie that it's a poor man's version of The Avengers and I wouldn't recommend watching this movie to anyone who expects the big group film quality that we've seen in the MCU.

Though director credit goes to Zack Snyder, the reality is that the director credit needs to go to Joss Whedon due to the number of reshoots he did thus changing Snyder's original vision to "Justice League".  This is not a bad film by any means and in my opinion, I think this is a vast improvement in quality when compared to nearly all prior DCEU (DC Extended Universe) films.  The problem lies that too much of Snyder's vision remains, this does not mesh well with Whedon's style and there are some awkward scenes as a result.  Whedon's execution is reminiscent of his work in the "Avengers" film, the problem is what worked there failed to work here.  In "Justice League", all these characters are just tossed to us without much exposition.  The reason this worked in "Avengers" is that all of their main characters were introduced in prior films, there was no need to revisit that.  "Justice League" tried doing the same but we are given many new characters with little to no explanation as to who they are or what their purpose is, they just serve as an uninspired plot device to get the story moving.  In regard to the cast, I do not believe I can criticize any of them because they are the victim of studio interference who's performance suffer as a result.  At the end of the day, "Justice League" feels like a generic but action-packed blockbuster.  It remains entertaining but there is no reason to revisit this film afterward.

The action is far better to match the tone of the current DC Universe WB was trying to establish and the story as a whole would definitely have done better for the franchise to set up individual movies for each new character as we were it made you more invested in them and you actual saw there growth in the movie.

Back when I saw this movie, I was really confused. Most of the logic in the film made no sense:
1. Superman is better than the entire Justice League combined. Then why does Justice League even exist when Superman can do everything alone, this film will never explain.
2. Superman is equally fast, if not faster, than Flash. Then why is Flash even a thing, this film will never explain.
3. Cyborg is good enough to be in Justice League, but Green Lantern and Martian Manhunter don't even exist. Why, this film will never explain.
4. Steppenwolf's army is so weak, even the warriors of Amazon and Atlantic people can beat the hell out of them. Then how are they even a threat, this film will never explain.
5. Superman blows out of his coffin because of which his shirt and coat get burnt away, but his pants are still on, showing him shirtless. Will the same thing happen with Wonder Woman also, this film will never explain.
And most importantly,
6. HOW ON EARTH (literally) IS AQUAMAN FIGHTING OUTSIDE WATER, AND THAT TOO WITH SUCH PERFECTION!?!?!
The only good scene in this whole film was when Superman was fighting with Flash in slow motion (or rather Flash was just trying to run away from Superman) for 30 seconds. But you can just watch that scene on YouTube. And it will seem even more entertaining without any context.
But later on I learnt about how Warner Bros had brought in Joss Whedon to finish the movie while Zack Snyder had left for his daughter's death and that completely butchered the movie. And after having watched the Snyder Cut I realised this movie was even worse than what I remembered. Although I don't hate Joss Whedon the way all these toxic Snyder stans do, he did a pretty terrible work here. He literally had just one job - consult Snyder and ask what has to be done, and then add CGI to the rough cut.
I think I will rewatch this movie one more time sometime in the future, when I have nothing better to do. Then I may even reconsider adding some more points in this review that I may have forgotten to write now.

The Russian family subplot was completely unnecessary and took away screentime that would have been a nice chance to improve the development of the characters named above.
The colour filter applied on the whole movie is awful.
Sometimes there's more irony than requested (flash motorboating Diana breasts, "something's definitely bleeding" and so on), Flash was turned into a clown.
In conclusion, the movie isn't good but isn't absolute trash, but if compared with ZSJL, it is.

This movie was just OK when it came out. But now having seen a version from its real director, it is genuinely shocking how many things, both large and small were changed by the uncredited stand in director Joss Whedon. And none of them for the better. Rewatching this version after the Snyder version, this feels like the lame quip filled, extra interpersonal conflict, overly comedic attempt at the same movie that it really is... which is doubly strange since this is the original theatrical film. I won't say cut, because this film is more than just a shorter theatrical version, at least half this Whedon movie wasn't in the real director's final movie, and much that was felt completely different through different framing, tone, music, dialogue, lighting, coloration, cgi,  etc... and again all of it worse in this version. So as I said, in a vacuum when it came out, this was a meh 2 1/2 star movie. But now it lives in a world where the real movie was released, and this store brand version was revealed for the lame attempt at the same story it really was...

I'd give this zero stars but you cant post a review without giving it at least half a star. Justice League is utterly pathetic and an embarrassment to Cinema. Everything that happened in the film happened because the script said so and there is no sense that there even needs to be a team. Superman comes in and does everything to save the day. He literally does everything, he destroys the villain who has zero character depth and character arc, Superman saves an entire building of children while everyone basically watches him saving the world with zero challenge. Imagine the rest of the cast on set filming this? Knowing the character your playing is doing nothing significant in the movie to save the day. The film offers no sense of meaning, there is no theme, and you never wonder what a character is thinking because everything their thinking is literally coming out of their mouth. I say this because the film doesn't give you a reason to pay attention to it, there's nothing to think about other than how the hell the cast went along filming this with a straight face.

This movie is just awful! Warner Bros should be ashamed of themselves. You have 3 of the most iconic heroes of all time and this is what you make? The CGI is embarrassingly bad for 2017 especially with the final battle, the jokes are so forced, unfunny and feel out of place and the plot is as generic and as thin as you can get with no layers. Steppenwolf is also one of the worst comic book villains ever. There's nothing interesting about him and let's talk about the characters. Batman is not Batman here; I refuse to believe this is the same Batman from BvS. Aquaman and Cyborg do nothing here, Flash just serves as unfunny comic relief. Wonder Woman is ok, same with Superman but it's inconsistent from the Superman from the other films. The tone is all over the place as well. The dialogue is terrible and the story feels so rushed. It's like there's a longer cut of the movie but it was cut down in the editing room. Oh, wait, that's what exactly happened! Overall, this is an embarrassing piece of failure. The only good things are the action scenes, acting and character interactions but even those are just above average. One of the worst superhero movies and an insult to Zack Snyder, DC and fans of DC and movies in general  (D-)

Possibly one of the worst comic book movies ever produced. This version reeks of studio meddling and out-of-touch committees in almost every measurable area.

Patty Jenkins who directed Wonder Woman and Wonder Woman 1984 stated the following and it should tell you everything you need to know about this dumpster fire: 

"I think that all of us DC directors tossed that (Joss Whedon's Justice League) out just as much as the fans did. But also, I felt that that version contradicted my first movie in many ways, and this current movie, which I was already in production on. So then, what are you going to do? I was like…you would have to play ball in both directions in order for that to work. The only thing I have done, and have always tried to do, is — I knew, when Zack was doing Justice League, where she sort of ends up. So I always tried…like, I didn't change her suit, because I never want to…I don't want to contradict his films, you know? But yet, I have to have my own films, and he's been very supportive of that. And so, I think that that Justice League was kind of an outlier. They were trying to turn one thing into, kind of, another. And so then it becomes, ‘I don't recognize half of these characters. I'm not sure what's going on.'"

Zack Snyder's Justice League comes out March 18th, 2021 on HBO Max. Go support artistic integrity and creative freedom by watching that instead if you want to watch a live-action Justice League, even if you don't like Zack's work.
Will await the actual release of this movie in 2021

Like many of the other DCEU properties that simply didn't live up to their potential, it's painfully obvious that this movie suffered from the "too many cooks in the kitchen" situation they found themselves (or put themselves) in throughout the process. I don't think there is another movie I've seen where it's more evident how muddled the vision became. It seems to me, and this is just an opinion, that the studio is to blame for trying to hard to catch the MCU and for not focusing on a singular vision, which would have delivered something more memorable to the fans. As you would suspect with such revered characters, it's full of really cool moments but ultimately misses the mark and doesn't deliver on the potential that the source material hands you on a silver platter. Just like BvS, this should be a movie you want to watch dozens of times and it's just not...at least not if you're being honest with yourself.

Justice League had its moments but, as a whole, I found it disappointing. The massive tonal shift from the dark and gritty Batman v. Superman to the fluffy and restrained Justice League is one of my biggest gripes with this film. The Batman character in particular feels like such a "180" from what we saw in Batman v. Superman. Furthermore, I felt that Steppenwolf was a pretty "run of the mill" cliche villain that I didn't find convincing enough. Perhaps more time spent building up his character and focusing on his motives would have improved that. Unfortunately, there is a lack of chemistry between the hero characters, likely as a result of the extremely rushed first act. Rather than setting up character relationships with substantial and meaningful dialogue, this film chooses to gloss over all of that and go straight to the CGI-filled action. As a result, the characters still didn't feel like they really knew each other even by the end of the film. Considering Man of Steel was about two and a half hours long and the Ultimate Edition of Batman v. Superman was over three, this film, where we see these iconic DC heroes teaming up for the first time in live action, should have been longer and more patient. Instead, they chose to cram this story into a two hour runtime and the result is a less than satisfying "team up" film with wasted potential.

I wish I could have rated this much higher. I really wanted to. I wanted to be able to dispel all of the criticism. Unfortunately, I can't. There are definitely some good parts and some potential. The nearly all the roles seem are well cast. But there are just too many places where they butchered it. You get a sense of how much they did in reshoots just even from how many of Henry Cavill's scenes show him with the weird mustache cover-up. How they weren't able to do that better is beyond me. The problems boil down to a few main things. Like BvS, they try to do WAY TOO MUCH world-building in a single movie. They introduce three new characters (Aquaman, The Flash, and Cyborg), bring back one that still has never had their own establishing movie (Batman), and desperate to show us both Themyscira and Atlantis. Their characterization of Bruce Wayne/Batman is completely wrong. Steppenwolf is not a very good villain. Pretty two dimensional. And the writing just isn't great. Clunky dialogue. Sloppy exposition. It just rings false too often. There is, however, enough potential here that I am very interested to see the Snyder cut in 2021. If that version fixes a significant number of these problems, they should make it canon and disregard this hack job.

The fact Batman V Superman is in the same universe is just strange because of the massive tonal shift between the two. The movie feels a little bit like a worse avengers that came out 5 when were 5 years beyond that. But in the end the movie just did not work for me.

Messy, cheesy, poorly written, with some awful performances. Still I think this is an improvement (slightly) over the nihilistic vision Zack Snyder had of the this universe. The reshoots are painfully obvious, within the same scene Affleck looks like the lean, tough Bruce Wayne of BVS (Snyder shots) and a moment later he looks miserable, overweight, and in need of serious rehab (Whedon shots). Whedon and Snyder have completely different styles and visions, and so we get a cut and paste patchwork of a movie that won't satisfy fans of either director. The best scene is when Superman fights the league and has some genuinely fun moments (flash's reaction to Superman's speed). Overall though I only was able to enjoy this movie in any way because my expectations were at rock bottom, I walked in expecting a disaster and that's what I saw. The CGI looks like it is 20 years old, Steppenwolf is a terrible villain- not only does he look terrible but his character gets absolutely zero development. Cavill's upper lip looks truly disturbing in some scenes, but at least he smiles a few times and seems to be enjoying himself a bit here (unlike MOS and BVS where he is a stale, mopey, sad Superman). I was a huge Justice League fan growing up, and if I had gone in expecting even a halfway decent movie I would have been horribly disappointed. However by the time Justice League came around I had long given up hope in the DCEU being any good at all. Oh well, some of the solo movies have been good (WW, Shazam), let's hope they can continue to make some good stand alones.

The very first scene of JUSTICE LEAGUE pretty much sums up the film in a way.

Superman had just finished a rescue mission, and kids are doing an interview with him for their blog. The point of view is from a shaky phone camera. The kids giddily ask the polite hero what's his favourite thing about Earth. 

He turns his head and thinks for a few seconds. He frowns. The answer should be easy, but it's not. He then smiles and turns back to the camera. He starts to speak and his words are cut short as the scene brutally ends.

It's probably my favourite scene of the film, showing a certain sense of poignancy in Henry Cavill's acting, and in the symbolic way the scene is cut short, the same way his life was in the unjustly maligned BATMAN V SUPERMAN. It has a charming sense of ''reality'' that has been lacking in a lot of the DC Films and translate well the inherent goodness of the Man of Steel as well as the admiration children may have for such a being.

It also demonstrates one of the movie's failings. A sense that something good may occur, but we are unable to reach that point exactly. We are left wanting more in the form of emotional involvement with the characters.

The following scene is a throwback to the last scene of BVS, where the world mourns its alien saviour, played beautifully to a Leonard Cohen song performed by Sigrid. While it is stylish and gorgeous, I am still unable to really feel the right amount of sympathy for Superman as he is portrayed in this latest incarnation. While I believe Cavill's turn as the Man of Steel is perfect casting, the way the character was handled was awkward at best, and the ending of MAN OF STEEL was apocalyptic enough that I can't understand how people would really miss the man who levelled a whole city during one of his battles. It just seems that he hasn't earned the worship that is thrown his way by the time BATMAN V SUPERMAN comes along. While the destruction of Metropolis is a good fodder for what transpires in BVS, giving Bruce Wayne reasons to see Superman as a threat, it also makes his status as a saviour a bit difficult to fathom.

But I digress. How is the JUSTICE LEAGUE movie?

I'm on the fence about it. You may have gotten from this blog that I am a good public for that type of film. Ever since I was watching the Batman TV show as a child, and was flabbergasted by the Donner SUPERMAN movie when I was 13 years old, I've had a soft spot for superhero films. They are just inherently perfect for the medium of film, offering clear heroes and villains, obvious obstacles to conquer, and if it fails dramatically, then there is the added bonus of seeing grown ups running around in goofy costumes. 

And while the Marvel movies have managed to capture lighting in a bottle, managing over and over again to find the right tone to treat those characters successfully in movies (to varying degrees of success, of course), with the exception of WONDER WOMAN, DC have been struggling steadily ever since they rebooted Superman with MAN OF STEEL. The tonally grim series didn't seem to gel with the audience, and while director Zach Snyder has an undeniable talent for some strong visuals and effective moments in films, as well as translating comic books to the screen with an insane amount of reverence  for the source material (one has to think of his exceptional 300 or WATCHMEN) he sometimes has a hard time tying all those moments together adequately in an effective and engaging narrative. 

So there were no small amounts of hope that when Snyder got replaced with Joss Whedon (who had done such an amazing job bringing the Marvel characters together in the wildly entertaining THE AVENGERS) to finish JUSTICE LEAGUE that maybe his magic touch may help out what could have been another dreary tale of superheroics. 

The results are unconvincing to say the least. The film ends up feeling like a Frankenstein monster, made up of ill-connecting parts. At times gloomy, and at times light hearted, it seems to have a hard time finding its proper footing, and truly engaging the viewer. 

Remember how awkward that scene in CIVIL WAR (an otherwise very fine movie) was, when Tony Stark ends up at Peter Parker's room to hire him in his vendetta against Captain America? How forced it felt, so that Spider-Man could finally be part of the Cinematic Marvel Universe? The whole first half of the film, as Batman and Wonder Woman goes around trying to recruit heroes for their mission in defeating Steppenwolf, a CGI MacGuffin that will unite them all in their quest, feels equally as forced. Not unpleasant, but forced. 

The rest of the story line moves  along at a fast pace, leaving little time to spend on characterization. And some developments are downright absurd, in that comic book kind of way. We all know that Superman HAS TO come back from the dead. And when he does, we are treated to a proper superhero fight that is undeniably a staple of the genre by now. The reasoning that leads to the resurrection, and the means to the end in itself, never rang true to me. It's one of those things you can't think too much about, or it will drive you mad. The verisimilitude proned by Richard Donner when he made SUPERMAN in 1978 is pretty much out the window.

As for the characters themselves, well, let's take them one at a time.

CYBORG, who sports a rather garish exoskeleton robotic body, has plenty of pathos, and there is a lot of potential to develop his troubled personae, where his human mind is overtaken at times by his mechanized self, but actor Ray Fisher doesn't have much opportunities to stretch his thespian muscles in this film. At the very least, a scene near the end of the film seem to imply a change of armour that will look closer to the more streamlined one viewed in the comics. As for exploring his pathos further, we are promised a movie somewhere down the line.

AQUAMAN, as portrayed with gusto by the robust Jason Momoa, is a striking departure from the oft mocked source material, whose essence was rather lame. In the film, he is closer in character to Marvel's Sub-Mariner, who shared with Aquaman a very similar origin. His exuberance is a stark contrast to Cyborg's grim self-hatred, but he seldom gets to use his water driven power in the film. I wish I would have seen him ''Talk to fishes'', something that will also be kept for his solo movie, no doubt.

THE FLASH is a curious mixed bag, as the interpretation by young Ezra Miller is dynamic and quirky, not unlike Tom Holland's Spider-Man. He steals most of his scenes, but certainly not with his costume, which is a certified eyesore. One can hope that, as Tony Stark did for Spidey, Bruce Wayne will help him upgrade his garment for something a bit more graceful. His relationship with his convict father is reminiscent of the one explored in the recent TV show, and it's safe to assume that his solo movie will deal with absolving his father's guilt . Rumour has it that it would be the FLASHPOINT storyline, (Already adapted in animation form in a fantastic straight to video DC film.) in which his attempts at travelling through time to prevent his mother's murder will create a series of paradox, including one where Bruce Wayne is the one who is murdered in that fateful alley, and the father takes on the mantle of Batman. Judging from the beginning of BVS, I look forward to Jeffrey Dean Morgan as Batman. 

As far as the depiction of his powers, they pale in comparison to the outstanding way super speed was portrayed in the latest two X-Men movies, where the scenes involving Quicksilver were spectacular showstoppers. 

WONDER WOMAN still benefits from the considerable charm and strength Gal Gadot managed to convey in her phenomenal solo movie earlier this year, and her scene stealing debut in BVS. Gadot has managed to stun the naysayers who doubted she had the physical attributes to play a comic book hero  and become a Wonder Woman every bit as memorable as Lynda Carter was in her own way.

Ben Affleck's BATMAN continues to impress, and still manages to stand out as one of the best movie Dark Knight out there. They have tried providing him with a lighter attitude, which is not always convincing. Rumours around states he may be replaced by Jake Gyllenhal in future films. Can't say I am enthusiastic about the prospect, but we'll see.

As stated before, Henry Cavill's SUPERMAN does return, and once again, there seems to have been an effort to lighten this character too, and in his case, it feels more natural. It seems a bit more like MY Superman, and I feel a bit more confident about his further adventures.

But will there be more adventures? As it stands now, the film hasn't made a killing at the box office, and after the dismal critical performances of SUICIDE SQUAD, MAN OF STEEL and BATMAN V SUPERMAN, one can imagine how nervous the producers must be at this point, trying to build a series in the mold of Marvel. There are already plans for films to be made out of this particular continuity.

But Marvel teamed up its characters in an organic way, introducing all of them in their own movies first, so that he viewer is already involved with them and the interactions just flow easier. In this case, half of the characters are brand new, and struggle to find their place in an especially busy story line ripped out straight from Jack Kirby's highly imaginative Fourth World saga.

Speaking of which, it's nice to see the King have his own isolated credit at the end of the film. A nice way to celebrate his 100 birthday. His touch in the film is not as visual as in THOR RAGNAROK, but more in his concepts pertaining to Darkseid, Apokolips, Steppenwof, the Mother Boxes, Boom Tubes and the Parademons. I'm still dreaming to see the actual New Gods up on the screen.

One last thing to mention is the score by Danny Elfman, who has travelled the roads alongside superhuman beings many times before. He does a serviceable job, whose highlights are mainly the use of leitmotivs from his own score to the 1989 BATMAN and John Williams' SUPERMAN. Can't say that there is much of a hummable theme to carry out of the theatre with me.

And that's the case pretty much of this JUSTICE LEAGUE. I didn't find the film offensively bad as some critics imply. I even liked some parts of it very much. I am curious to see more adventures with those characters, but not particularly eager. I need a bit more emotional attachment to the characters, which has yet to be build upon. I need more scenes like the reunion between Clark, Lois and Martha in a field, which felt warm and real, while a lot of the film feels a bit cold and artificial.

Like the heroes in the movie, DC Films are trying to break through the creeping gloominess that pervades that series, like the tendrils of Apokolips ravaging through the countryside. Unlike the Justice League, they succeed only partly.

Yes Justice League has many problems, but for some reason, I still enjoyed watching it. 

The good:
- I liked Barry Allen
- Action was cool
- The chemistry between the characters was there
The bad:
- The visual effects were really bad and obvious. 
- Weak villain and therefore a weak plot.
- Sometimes the comedy was not needed in the scene. For example when Batman was on the ground after Superman threw him he said something about internal bleeding. This did not seem like Batman at all and was definately not needed. The comedy felt as though DC was trying to replicate all of The Avengers's movies comedy, but sometimes in the movie it wasn't needed at all. 
- The backstories to the other characters (Cyborg, Flash, and Aquaman) felt a little rushed, and even after watching the movie, we still don't know much about them. 
- Logic issues and questions. Why was Superman attacking Batman if they became friends at the end of BvS? Why were they even fighting in the underground sewer in the first place? Why was Steppenwolf even there? 

The movie overall felt like it was trying to correct the mistakes it made in BvS and at the same time replicate The Avengers but with DC characters. But despite these flaws, I still enjoyed the movie and I find it to be very rewatchable. This is also a good step up from BvS and Suicide Squad when it comes to Warner Brothers making a movie with a group of DC characters.

Not as stirring or exciting as the first appearance of the team on film should have been, it is lighter than their onscreen last outing; sporadically funny and moving, even if it doesn't get the balance right, with levity undercutting the drama in places, but taking itself too seriously in others with characters being world-weary and talking in raspy whispers. So it lacks the energy it should, but after Batman v Superman it's simply a result that it's enjoyable and not a slog to get through. It doesn't do anything original and may not do these characters justice but it doesn't do them any great injustice either: it gets their core traits right, has some iconic moments and is steeped in DC universe lore; although overall quality still makes it only really recommendable for fans who will get the most out of this.

Why do I get the feeling that when they had casting calls for this movie, they just went with whoever's the most good-looking, famous, or can fill up the diversity placeholder? The whole film looks expensive and it had all the primary parts to construct an effective superhero film but why wasn't it successful at executing it? It seems like DC learns the hard way that not even Jason Momoa can salvage something as gratuitous as ‘Justice League'—which is a shame, really. It's these things that make all the difference and continue to place the DC Extended Universe steps below their wildly successful comic franchise counterpart. Don't get me wrong, Henry Cavill as Superman/Clark Kent and Gal Gadot as Wonder Woman/Diana Prince hit just the right notes but the rest seemed like  an irredeemable mess from the start. They made Scarlett Johansson and Tilda Swinton in their problematic Marvel roles look good. I know many were skeptic about Ben Affleck playing Batman but we're all thrilled to know he mostly played a guy dressed as a bat and throughout the film, he's astute enough to remind us so. On the upside, the film is two hours long–long enough for fans to be unable to render the good parts with the atrocious so it all levels out in the end. Don't get me wrong; in reference to the parts that could have made this film effective, there were a few points that kept this from being a total waste. The blatant attempt at humour that was absent from earlier films were, at best, almost passable. The visuals were also crisp and very promising—one of many in a see of would-have-beens. I mourn for the fans.

This is supposed to be the DCEU's equivalent to Marvel's mighty "Avengers" quartet, I don't think so. "Justice League" is a mediocre superhero gathering of Batman (Ben Affleck once again missing the bar), Wonder Woman (Gal Gadot is worth cheering for),  Cyborg (Ray Fischer with some heart), the Flash and Aquaman (Ezra Miller and Jason Momoa bringing the humor) after the tragic death of Superman (Henry Cavill). The action sequences are mostly yawn-worthy, and the villain, Steppenwolf, a big CGI'd piece of ugliness, isn't worth the price of admission. The acting is alright, and it has its moments, but despite being marginally better than "Suicide Squad", it ends yet another disappointment for the growing franchise.
45/100

I mean let's just say it like it is, Justice League is not good. But it is fun. Not in a good way though. It's completely rubbish. But it's still entertaining. Not because it's good. But because it's relentlessly, perfectly stupid. It all plays like a Saturday morning cartoon. And even though it's a total mess, it's de-Snydered enough to not be as much of a dark, dull dirge as Batman V Superman. It makes The Avengers look like The Godfather Part II. Aquaman and the guy that played Cyborg were surprisingly good. Ezra Miller breaks even on the annoying/adorkable front. And Affleck is still a decent actor in a dodgy suit and a flaccid, jibbering thankless role.
It's 90% exposition and contrivance, 90% CGI and 110% reshoots. Basically think of everything bad that happens in movies you hate and this one pretty much has it all. It even has four poor Russians living near a nuclear reactor who have cracks in the wall with the shotgun on it, candles because, you know, they're poor, and a Russian nesting doll because, you know, they're Russians. That's basically says it all about this move. Neither Snyder, nor Whedon, nor Warners are at fault for this movie alone; absolutely every single person that worked on it from caterers to casting agents, from runners to ringleaders should all equally share the blame for this fairly inoffensive but undoubted waste of everybody's time.

Although it does have a lot of issues (like the tone shifts, the rushed nature of the film compared to the MCU, the overpoweredness of Superman), Justice League is entertaining to watch and you can have fun with it.

Maybe not up to Avengers levels, but this was a fairly serviceable way to introduce new characters and allow for new storylines to begin as we go forward in the DCEU. The moustache did not bother me as it seems to bother others. From what I could see though, the upper lip CGI was only in the scene at the beginning with the little kids asking him questions about himself and his love of Earth. During his subsequent scenes after being resurrected, it appeared to be all Cavill. Speaking of Cavill, he looked absolutely amazing. I have always admired the men and women in the MCU and DCEU (also the TV shows) and the efforts they have made to look the parts. As a fan of superhero live action adaptations, I salute the men and women who put themselves and their bodies through absolute hell for our entertainment. Jason Momoa was awesome as Aquaman, the sequence with him sitting on the Lasso of Truth was awe inspiring and showed his range as Arthur. Ezra Miller as Flash can grow on me, but I will probably always prefer Grant Gustin from the TV show. Gal Gadot and Ben Affleck stole the show as they showed that they can have good chemistry together on screen. Going forward with out Batfleck might be troublesome but doable in my mind. This movie works in its own world as a part of the DCEU but was a bit rushed by Warner Bros with Avengers: Infinity War right around the corner and the success Marvel was having with their interweaving storylines. Teasing us with a Justice League vs Injustice League sequence of movies may allow us to really flesh out all these characters and also introduce new actors in established roles. A must watch for any DC movie lover.

Full disclosure, we saw this movie last week but accidentally missed the first 30 minutes and didn't realize it until we got out and it wasn't as late as it should have been. Slightly it was good, and slightly it was bad. Good because of the cast of characters that were in it. Bad was how awful the CGI was. Good because they worked as a team, and had plus and minuses with the characters. Bad was how they tried to loophole it with a cut and dry script which was part of how a 'studio' wants it done. What's my verdict? It was a good, fun movie, but it had so much interference from the studio that they blocked out what was good in the first place. It kickstarted the franchise with the characters but they weren't given enough time before they jumped ahead and put their own stamp of being an Avengers ripoff. Now I'm a big comic fan. I like both DC characters as well as Marvel. There was just too much input with this. We needed to establish a Flash film, Aquaman film, Cyborg film, then this would've been okay to do...but seeing them try to remove and add a mustache' from Superman, it looked awkward. There wasn't enough chances to grow with the characters who were just introduced. This was a chance for filmmakers to do their jobs, not some money milking suit and tie guys. It was directed by two guys. Zack Snyder and Joss Whedon. Totally opposite poles. This was shoved into theaters with not enough care. Then what happened then? We had an Aquaman movie. It was good! Then we had Shazam! I hadn't seen it, but I hear it's worthwhile. Working on spin-off's with them, I think that was where the logic lies. Set up a long string, then do the Justice League while it's hot. I think this could've been a four star movie. But as of now, it seemed like there was too many cooks in this kitchen.

Thousands of years ago, Steppenwolf and his legions of Parademons attempted to take over Earth with the combined energies of three Mother Boxes. They were foiled by a unified army that included the Olympian Gods, Amazons, Atlanteans, mankind, and a Green Lantern. After repelling Steppenwolf's army, the Mother Boxes were separated and hidden in locations on the planet. In the present, mankind is in mourning over Superman for two years, whose death triggers the Mother Boxes to reactivate and Steppenwolf's return to Earth. In an effort to regain favor with his master Darkseid, Steppenwolf aims to gather the boxes to form "The Unity", which will destroy Earth's ecology and terraform it in the image of Steppenwolf's homeworld. Steppenwolf retrieves the Mother Box from Themyscira, prompting Queen Hippolyta to warn her daughter Diana (Gal Gadot) of Steppenwolf's return. Diana joins Bruce Wayne (Ben Affleck) in his attempt to unite other metahumans to their cause, with Wayne going after Arthur Curry (Jason Momoa) and Barry Allen (Ezra Miller), while Diana tries to locate Victor Stone (Ray Fisher). Wayne fails to persuade Curry, but manages to recruit an enthusiastic Allen onto the team. Although Diana fails to convince Stone to join, he agrees to help them locate the threat if he discovers their location. Stone later joins the team after his father Silas and several other S.T.A.R. Labs employees are kidnapped by Steppenwolf seeking to acquire the Mother Box from mankind. Steppenwolf attacks an Atlantean outpost to retrieve the next Mother Box, forcing Curry into action. The team receives intel from Commissioner James Gordon leading them to Steppenwolf's army, based in an abandoned facility under Gotham Harbor. Although the group manages to rescue the kidnapped employees, the facility is flooded during combat, which traps the team until Curry helps delay the flood so they can escape. Stone retrieves the last Mother Box, which he had hidden, for the group to analyze. Stone reveals that his father used the Mother Box to rebuild Stone's body after an accident almost cost him his life. Wayne decides to use the Mother Box to resurrect Superman (Henry Cavill), not only to help them fight off Steppenwolf's invasion, but also to restore hope to mankind. Diana and Curry are hesitant about the idea, but Wayne forms a secret contingency plan in case Superman returns as hostile...

Justice League received mixed reviews. It was praised for its action sequences and acting (primarily by Gadot and Miller) but criticized for the screenplay, pacing and CGI, as well as its thin plot, and the underdeveloped villain. Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "Justice League leaps over a number of DC movies, but its single bound isn't enough to shed the murky aesthetic, thin characters, and chaotic action that continue to dog the franchise." Richard Roeper of the Chicago Sun-Times gave the film 3.5 out of 4 stars, praising the cast, especially Gadot, and saying "It's a putting-the-band-together origins movie, executed with great fun and energy." Writing for Rolling Stone, Peter Travers gave the film 2.5 out of 4 stars, praising the cast but criticizing the action sequences and writing, saying: "The scenes of the League members together, bickering and bonding, spike the film with humor and genuine feeling, creating a rooting interest in the audience. Without it, the film would crumble." Conversely, Todd McCarthy of The Hollywood Reporter, while praising Gadot and Miller, called the film visually ugly and boring, saying, "Fatigue, repetition and a laborious approach to exposition are the keynotes of this affair, which is also notable for how Ben Affleck, donning the bat suit for the second time, looks like he'd rather be almost anywhere else but here."

It still boggles my mind how DC Comics continuously fails with their superhero universe on screen compared to what Marvel does. Great ones from DC is "Wonder Woman" and "Man Of Steel", while "Justice League" is hardly amongst the great ones. With an estimated production budget of $300 million, Justice League is one of the most expensive films ever made. The film grossed $657 million worldwide against a break-even point of $750 million, becoming a box office bomb and losing the studio an estimated $60 million. Predictable plot, uninspiring storyline, bad pacing, underdeveloped villain, strange character development and the overuse of CGI are major flaws in this film. I hate what they have done with The Flash and the same goes for Aquaman and what´s going on with the Cyborg character? While Ben Affleck simply can´t play Batman. Gal Gadot and Henry Cavill are ok, but not half as good as they are in "Wonder Woman" and "Man Of Steel". However, the fact is that the film suffered from the change of original director Zach Snyder (whom I think normally delivers) due to a personal tragedy which led also to the disposal of the movie's original composer Junkie XL and a re-editing of the film. Director Joss Whedon was called in to finish the film and I assume that was not all that easy for him as well. With a budget of $300 million the film should logically look and be so much better than the end result. "Justice League" is simply a foul ball and a failure. Pass on this.

This movie should have been delayed a solid 5 years to build up the characters and their solo movies first and then get a different director.

This film is much better than BVS and Suicide Squad, But that doesn't say much, unlike those films this one actually had reasons for behind the scenes mishaps at the wake of Snyder's Family tragedy and Whedon's direction. Which in the end delivers a jumbled mess of a film, but unlike BVS and Suicide Squad there is a love of the material going into the film that I previously couldn't find in the other films. The cast is exceptional Gal Gadot fresh off of Wonder Woman is still killing it with her performance, Jason Mamoa is fun and charming in his role as Aquaman, Fisher as Cyborg gives a grounded and comic accurate portrayal and even Cavill is starting to have more fun as the Man Of Steel. Afleck is good, but he looks like he's much less interested than in BVS which is a disappointment to me, Miller gives a funny and nice performance as The Scarlet Speedster, But I personally as a Flash(TV) fan can't see anyone but Grant in the role, which I know is wrong, but Grant does a great job. The visuals are a huge downgrade from BVS and Wonder Woman and it feels like playing a video game sometimes, Steppanwolf is a terrible villain who doesn't pose a threat at all, and the plot of collecting the motherboxes also feels like a video game plot, but in the end it's still nice to some of the best superheroes ever on screen together, it could've been so much more, but for what we got it was okay, and I'd watch it again.

Like Avengers, an omnipotent being is here to destroy the earth, in this case Steppenwolf.  What?  Who?  Yea I laughed everytime they said his name.  He may be a strong, albeit minor character in the DC universe, on film it was just silly.  Gadot and Momoa are great, Cavill is excellent as Superman but having him swinging away in front of a green screen for the last third of the movie means he does not bring a lot to the table.  I don't have a problem with Affleck, Miller was a mixed bag and perhaps that was due to the two different directors.  Now for Fisher's Cyborg, WTF.  A bizarre suit design, poor CGI, poor editing to the point where at different scenes he was not scaled to size and another where he was pasted in wrong.  Seems like this would of been a better second movie with the first one having the hero's putting all the villains in Suicide Squad in prison.  The end credit scene has promise but frankly I would be happy with just a series of Wonder Woman and Aquaman movies, with them teaming up.

The movie uses its great cast better than other entries in the DCEU; nevertheless, the shift in cinematography from scene to scene is simply too great. The styles of Zach Snyder and Joss Whedon crass and burn, despite the film giving some hope to the DCEU.

Unfortunately, this movie doesn't hold up for me upon repeated viewings. It's not an awful movie, but it needed to be way better. I actually liked Batman v. Superman better 'cause I felt that despite its flaws, it was unique. This feels like what it is: a pieced together movie that was meant to be dark, but turned Marvel-esque. If this movie came out in 2000 or even 2010 it would probably be regarded way better, but it feels underwhelming and the story just wasn't right.

This was not the film we were promised. Not even close. 

The trailers promised a spectacle that rivalled the Avengers if not surpassed it. The theatrical film proper was underwhelming in comparison. It was a clumsy and uneven blend of two different styles; not surprising as it had two different directors. 

The performances were good in some parts and awesome in others. Jason Momoa definitely lived up to the hype. Ezra Miller was just as funny as Grant Gustin and came off as very realistic. Ray Fisher wasn't as present, but all of his scenes were great and I really hope to see more of him. Gal Gadot didn't have the same flair as she did from her previous films but she was wonderful nonetheless; in both action and non-action scenes. Ben Affleck was all right but one could tell that he was not enjoying himself. Henry Cavill had some great moments but they were heavily shadowed by the horrid CGI editing to remove his moustache. And Ciaran Hinds was even worse than Christopher Eccleston from Thor: The Dark World though that is less his fault than it is those who removed his other scenes.

It does not help that Danny Elfman chose to use his classic Batman theme instead of trying to go a different route. On one hand, I acknowledge that he a had a short amount of time to work with. On the other, it seems that he would not have done anything differently if he did have more time.

All in all, the film tried too hard to be like the Marvel Cinematic Universe yet not enough to actually succeed. The movie's tone is cheesy, turgid and ultimately uninspired. 

Conclusion: Release The Snyder Cut

Give us the Snyder Cut!

Strengths: Itâ(TM)s no secret that the DC movie universe has struggled. The one thing that theyâ(TM)ve gotten incredibly right was casting Gal Gadot (Diana Prince/Wonder Woman). She was the best part of Batman v. Superman, great in her solo film, and was the highlight here. I also liked Jason Momoa (Arthur Curry/Aquaman). He brought a charisma to the character that I never expected and was another highlight. Ezra Miller (Barry Allen/The Flash) also had some delightful scenes. Another thing I like about DC films is their fight scenes. They often feel realistic and hard hitting. This movie had some of that. At two hours, itâ(TM)s shorter than a lot of superhero movies and it actually does fly by surprisingly quickly.

Weaknesses: I still canâ(TM)t get behind Ben Affleck (Bruce Wayne/Batman) in this role, while the CGI used on Henry Cavill (Clark Kent/Superman) was so distracting, I couldnâ(TM)t take any of his scenes seriously. A lot of the CGI in this movie just looked bad, to be honest. The villain and his army are a terrible CGI fest. Ciaran Hinds (Steppenwolf) tries, but the character has nothing to him. Heâ(TM)s unbelievably generic and you never feel like heâ(TM)s a true threat. I also thought the underwater scenes looked bad. It looks much better in the Aquaman trailers. The plot is disjointed. It seems like they tried way too many things and none of them stick. Itâ(TM)s hard to compare this to the MCU, but one reason their team up movies work is because of the chemistry among the cast. This group doesnâ(TM)t really have that. Ray Fisher (Victor Stone/Cyborg) is another actor who tries, but is given next to nothing to work with.

Overall: I enjoyed some of the performances and characters, as well as a hint of the action. The story just completely lets everyone down and it isnâ(TM)t helped by bad special effects and a poor villain.

A disappointing movie, but not a bad one. Justice league manages to make likable characters that you have fun watching even if you aren't able to fully appreciate the fact that all of these characters are in the same movie. This movie was rushed, and you can tell after watching Aqua-man. Aqua-man actually made Justice league better. You get to see Aqua-man's powers explored along with strong character development. That is what Justice league needed because you spend to much time getting to like the characters, and finding out what they can do rather than already liking them, and knowing who they are and what they can do, and there is not a lot of time with these characters in this movie to begin with, only a mere 2 hours ten minutes of which is the end credits. Justice league also suffers from a divided tone. It is clear that there were two different directors with two different visions of this film. The first two thirds of this film give a glimpse of what this movie could have been with some hints of Josh Weadon's vision, but over all was still Zack Snyder's movie then the third act comes, and you realize how much potential was lost in this film. This movie also needed the many scenes that were removed, and we know they exist due to the trialers. This movie was enjoyable, but not all that we should have gotten.

This is not a bad film, like The Emoji Movie bad, it's a fun movie that brought the JLA together. The performances were really good, especially Ezra Miller as Barry Allen/The Flash, almost everything out of his mouth is hilarious. Though I admit there are a few bad things in this movie, I thought Superman's return from the dead was kind of anti-climatic and deus ex machina, and the movie occasionally struggles to add the Zack Snyder aesthetic in the more fun tone in the film. Really the main problem as to why this film and the darker and more convoluted BvS: Dawn of Justice Theatrical Edition both failed is because of one thing: studio interference. Zack Snyder left post-production of this movie because of a family tragedy and the studio brought in Joss Whedon (writer and director of this movie's rival The Avengers and it's first sequel) to supervise post-production, but at the same time they also ordered re-writes and reshoots to make the film more upbeat than Snyder's original vision (which I thought would have been really good) and Snyder received sole director's credit. The same thing with the Theatrical Edition of BvS, the studio ordered random cuts of that movie, regardless of how important they were to the story, and the Ultimate Edition was the version it was supposed to be before it started.

While not being the worst superhero movie, it is DEFINITELY not the best. It is hard to have a Justice League movie and not have Superman in it for half of the film. When every superhero trying to be dark like Batman, I am not even sure if Superman would want to return! Honestly, when your making Flash dark AND super awkward, you think, "Even tv can to the Flash better than the movies." 

   The villain, Stephen Wolfe, was so bad that you probably just found out what his name was. He was such a bad villain that there was emotional tension between the Justice League and him, it's literally the Justice League trying to stop Stephen Wolfe because... He is bad. Don't make a villain that his only purpose is to fill in the spot of a villain. I wonder what they were thinking when they decided that Stephen Wolfe would be the bad guy, when choosing a villain for iconic superheroes, don't use someone you've never heard of. 

   And then comes the plot... that one bad guy trying to steal boxes to do evil things and getting stopped by a newly formed band of low-budget superheroes--- what a great plot. But actually I think that they probably should have introduced a few more characters and established a big, bad guy before making, what will probably be the most important movie of the DCEU. Overall, Justice League is underdeveloped, if it would have been given more before it was made, and maybe a better plot, Justice League could have been a really good movie.

What in the world were they thinking when they made this movie. In an attempt to compete with Marvel Warner Brothers threw away every Justice League hero for mood and action scenes. The villain in this film is laughable at best and is so cardboard that you feel no threat from him at all. He spouts one liners and says: "No, this can't be." like every cartoon character who was a bad guy in history. The only saving grace to this film is Gal Gadot's Wonder Woman and the film knew this based on promotional material. The new heroes introduced are so forced and desperate to imprint on audiences that they are given traits over personalities to define them. Flash is nervous and talks too much like a man pumped with caffine. Cyborg walks all tough like and whispers somberly. Aquaman is made into a tough biker with tattoos who says: "Yeah" whenever he does something cool. Snyder does not care about anything but the mood and the second director who's name I don't want to mention, thus tarnishing his reputation further only slaps in quirky humor.  It's a mess really and unfortunately this film was set up to never have opportunities in the first place due to the rushed nature of production. When a franchise is raced out to be competitive and cash in on fan nostalgia without any regard for story or quality control this is the end result. If you like loud noises and lots of superficial explosions then grab some popcorn and enjoy. If you want to take your DC universe seriously just watch Nolan's Batman, Wonder Woman, Aquaman and the first two Christopher Reave Superman renditions.

So many walls crumble from so many thrown bodies (Hollywood's go-to kinetic kitsch), as reluctant heroes grapple with two MacGuffins (one of which would have been better served by trademarking "MacGuffin") against a mocap zealot from the realm of the Uncanny Valley, while trading quips, awkward conversastional platitudes, and obvious directorial styles in a runtime that would've been served by being both longer and shorter at the same time. Unlike the comics, you could get chills watching him do stuff. Cyborg was impressive, especially his CGI. As far as I'm aware this was the first live-action movie Cyborg. Henry, Affleck and Gadot had fine parts. There were so many references that make me excited for the upcoming Shazam, Flash, Wonder Woman and Joker movie and sequels.

I would recommend this if you liked any one of the previous DCEU movies. I would age it 12 for strong violence, language, and spooky scenes. I do believe for the future of the DCEU.

This was a pretty bad movie. Miles better than Dawn of Justice and Suicide Squad, but worse than Man of Steel. Justice League is the third worst DCEU film. Justice League was the worst DC film and worst comic book movie of 2017. Justice League was the most disappointing film of 2017 (not the worst cause it's totally far from the worst, just the most disappointing). There were at least some good things I liked about this movie, but sadly the negatives outweigh the positives. I liked some of the action scenes. I liked the bank robbery scene at the beginning and I liked the part where Superman showed up in the third act and defeated Steppenwolf. In that final battle scene in the third act, he was actually fortunately felt like the classic comic book Superman perfectly portrayed by Christopher Reeve. So that thankfully means no more mopey, gloomy, emo, depressed Superman anymore. At the end of the movie, we finally got the colorful, jolly Superman we all wanted in the DCEU since Man of Steel (even if it was just for a while in the end of the final act and in the resolution). Another thing I liked about this film was Aquaman's "cool guy entrance" when he was first introduced into the film. I liked Joe Morton as Victor Stone's (a.k.a. Cyborg) dad. He was perfectly cast in that role. That role was definitely made for him (even if it was just a small role). I thought at least some of the humor was amusing. Now the negatives....  Batman gave away his identity to the other members of the Justice League. So now Wonder Woman, Aquaman, the Flash, and Cyborg all know him as Bruce Wayne. That ruins his character, because the Batman I grew up with from the source material, comics, and Justice League animated series never trusted anyone (other than his butler Alfred). He never gave his identity away to the others members of the Justice League in the comics and shows. Batman is supposed to have trust issues. In this movie, he very easily and intentionally gave away his identity to Diana Prince, Arthur Curry, Barry Allen, and Victor Stone. That automatically ruins the character of Batman. Diana Prince a.k.a. Wonder Woman bitches about her old dead boyfriend, Steve Trevor, too much in this film. Barry Allen a.k.a. the Flash was too comedic and kept cracking jokes. Barry Allen is supposed to be the serious and emotional Flash, not the humorous wise-cracking Flash. Wally West is supposed to be the humorous, funny, wise-cracking Flash. In fact, Wally West is supposed to be the Justice League Flash, not Barry Allen. The movie got it all wrong. Oh, and we should've gotten a Flash solo movie before Justice League so he could've gotten much better character development. We the audience barely got to connect with him in this movie cause we barely knew him in this film. Now, Aquaman....I personally feel that Jason Momoa should've played Lobo instead of Aquaman. Speaking of which, Aquaman should've gotten his own solo movie before Justice League. We barely got to know him in this movie and he had very little character development. Cyborg should have been first established in a DCEU Teen Titans movie or in his own DCEU solo movie before being in a Justice League movie. We barely got to know him in this movie, so he had poor character development. The amount of terrible CGI in this movie was ridiculous. Some scenes in the movie even kind of looked like a video game because of the overuse of CGI in which the visuals looked terrible. The villain, Steppenwolf, was a very forgettable villain, disappointing, and wasted super villain. His motivation was questionable and nonexistent. I also felt that there was a lack of chemistry with the cast and characters in the movie. The DCEU probably needs a reboot. The DCEU is a trainwreck and a big mess. Wonder Woman is still the only good DCEU film. Justice League had a lot of potential, but it was sadly wasted. Warner Bros. Pictures/DC Entertainment shouldn't have rushed to play catch-up with Marvel Studios/Marvel Entertainment. I feel like DC needs their own studio. They need their own version of Marvel Studios called "DC Studios". Warner Bros. is just ruining DC's live-action movie rep on the big screen.

Alas! The culmination of the 'Worlds of DC' is finally upon us! The crossover hot of the heels of the critically acclaimed 'Wonder Woman' introduces new threats to the Earth which our heroes must unite to battle. The standout star of this movie, a decision perhaps pushed by Warner Bros. after the success of her standalone adventure, is Wonder Woman (Gal Gadot). See is the only hero with a true sense of purpose in this film; Batman is lost after the death of Superman, Superman is, well dead, and the other heroes are on their own. Perhaps what this feature does best is introduce us to new characters, reintroduce the trinity and get underway with its plot all in two hours - with a longer runtime this movie would have thrived. 

'Justice League' monumentally changes the tone of this movie universe with less serious plots and personalities - the introduction of Barry Allen primes the quirkiness of the universe. Ezra Miller's Flash is the youthful, energetic 'child' of the group that draws in many laughs from the audience. Yet many are discrediting the movie due to the apparent loss of Zack Snyder's unique vision set up through 'Man of Steel' and 'Batman V. Superman: Dawn of Justice'. While true, his vision has been traded for a much more enjoyable and comic-accurate representation of all the heroes. 

The plot of this movie is by no means a cinematic masterpiece, but the movie itself is an engaging battle between six vastly differing heroes with unique and incompatible personalities (Aquaman and Cyborg would certainly create a unique 'Bro-duo' in the sequel). 

I recommend to any big fans of the DC brand.

SPOILERS When I first saw Justice League, I thought it was very, very good. Sure, there were problems, but I thought that overall it was a very fun and entertaining film. Now, one year later, I've began to really notice its problems. This realization came after I saw Avengers: Infinity War. The whole movie was about Thanos trying to get all the infinity stones so he can do what he wants to the universe, and does so at the end. (That's basically a quick summary; I know there's much more to it) And all the heroes spend the whole movie going planet by planet, battle to battle, trying to stop him from getting each of the six stones. This one premise makes up for what ends up being, in my opinion, the best film in the MCU. And the upcoming sequel will focus on the aftermath of Thanos getting all the stones and snapping half the universe out of existence. Justice League is kind of like this; the main villain, Steppenwolf (who is an underdeveloped, boring villain) is searching for 3 mother boxes, which will allow him and his army to conquer the world. About 3 quarters into the movie, he's already done this. The rest of the movie then followed the League trying to stop him from continuing his plans now that he has the 3 boxes. It all feels rushed. This movie was originally gonna be two parts, which probably means they would split getting the boxes and the aftermath into two separate parts. And boy, I really wish they did that. That's just one problem. The CGI is bad is most cases (they couldn't even take off Henry Cavil's mustache successfully), and at this point, with all the rumors that Henry Cavil is leaving the DCEU, I kind of wish they just kept Superman dead. But there are very funny moments in the movie. The Flash, for example, is hilarious in every scene he's in. Aquaman is also very funny. This is a fun movie, and it didn't meet the mark, but I accept it for what it is. So now, a year after I saw the film, I'd just consider the film to be good. But it does leave me excited for the future of the DCEU.

Justice League was completely terrible. The beginning actually started off good with the somber mood and absence of Superman. Then it got lazy and cringy. Such a waste of good characters. The TV Shows are much better than the movies. One of the main problems with this movie is that they tried to rival Marvel which is absolutely impossible. Marvel is too far ahead. But the one thing I absolutely hated about this movie was the overuse of Superman. He is not that strong! Why would I want to watch a movie that makes me think the villain is all powerful and is unstoppable just to have some idiot in a red cape giggle and defeat him. And that scene where he defeated the entire Justice League was completely unrealistic. The fight would have been over the second Wonder Woman had stepped in. Especially when the Flash stepped in. I have honestly never been more angered, upset, and disappointed by a superhero movie than with Justice League.
Weird dialogue and jokes coupled with bad acting. The whole plot felt rushed. CGI poor as well.

Does this film suffer? Yes. Is it fun? Yes. Rushed? Perhaps. In the end it is still a fun time. If DC is your thing then you will still enjoy this. I mean cmon man. Its the Justice League! on the big screen. The interactions make sense, the world flows together with all the previous and future films. You can finally see structure in the DCEU. It does suffer at many points, mustache, but it still succeeds at others. A grounded, fun-loving Aquaman. An awkward Flash. Queen Wonder Woman. Brutal Batman. Cyborg and Superman have jokes. My gosh ignore all the plot points and just enjoy this film.

I'm going to make the review of the movie Justice League. The director of the movie is Zack Snyder. The genre of the movie is a superhero movie. The movie's setting is on the earth. Simmons, etc. Ben Affleck as Batman, Henry Cavill as Superman, Gal Gadot as Wonder Woman, Ezra Miller as The Flash, Jason Momoa as Aquaman and Ray Fisher as Cyborg. The movie is about that the world in under the menace from Steppenwolf and Batman, without Superman, has to build a team that can help him to stop Steppenwolf. 
The story from the movie isn't the best because at almost the end of the movie, all the team us losing and Superman appears and defeat the villain very easy. So that means that it wasn't necessary to make the team.
The cinematography was very good because in some scenes they were on another part that wasn't the earth and they created the place so real.
The soundtrack was very good but it wasn't perfect. We can compare Suicide Squad soundtrack to this one and you will see the difference.
The best scenes were the fight scenes from the movie because they are so edited that they look real.
The special effects were good but the villain, that was made by CGI, wasn't perfect.
I would give this movie 7/10.
The fans are going to be happy because they will see the most iconic group of superheroes on the big screens and the movie respects the essential feeling from the Justice League.
People should see it because it's entertaining and if you want to have a great time you should see it.
