I've never been the biggest fan of the DCEU (Wonder Woman being the outlier), but up until now there was always at least one thing I could appreciate about each film. I can't really say that for this one. The visuals weren't nearly as good as its predecessors (and considering this cost like 300 mil, thats inexcusable), Every character is butchered in some way, the story is just everywhere, this movie was just a colossal mess and I really hoped it wouldn't be.

I'm not sure how the DCEU can come back from this. There's been a shakeup at the top so hopefully a course correction is coming soon.

It may have ticked a lot of boxes but felt for the most part devoid of heart. I liked it and yet felt completely underwhelmed by the final product.

Let me preface this by saying I had been a fan of all entries to the DCEU. Man of Steel told the great tale of a man rejecting his heritage to save his home from annihilation. Batman V Superman: DOJ told the tale of misplaced anger and how fear can be manipulated to leave the world in more exposed place than it was before. Wonder Woman told the tale of a sheltered demi god coming to the front to save the world from death and oppression.

What Justice League meant to do and failed to deliver was how weary outsiders can overcome the hardships in their lives and band together to save a world they are once again finding hope in.

I do not lay the blame at the hands of either of the directors. Zack Snyder was hoping to realise another part of his large vision that he set up in BvS and Joss Whedon had the unenviable task of coming in to direct reshoots under really hamstringing circumstances.
The fault for me lies with the studio and the heads of DC films (looking your way Mr Johns). The reason I take this viewpoint is simple I think Warner Bros were too narrow minded in their thinking that the general audience looking to see this movie would not be able to handle a 2.5 hour runtime and a silly idea that every tentpole movie needs to make $1bn to be a success. It did not help either that the marketing provided to be too much of a mixed bag.
 Geoff Johns proved that he was way out of his depth with this movie. I think he was too eager to be seen the one bringing a much needed change to the style of the movie, ultimately too it's detriment. I believe he amended Chris Terrio's screenplay too much to reduce any perceived darkness and when that wasn't working to hire another writer for reshoots and ultimately when that approach did not work, to let "fans" throw both under the bus. The proof is in the pudding as he now no longer serves as head of DC films.
Ultimately the efforts of both of these contributing factors result in a movie that feels less like a hopeful action epic, than a $250m apology that DC can still get things right.

Zack Snyder for his part manages to keep some of his vision for the characters intact, albeit under restrictive conditions. Joss Whedon for his part tries his hardest to create a cohesive picture however I just believe too much was changed. Instead of meaningful arcs and good storytelling I got a cool action comedy.

In the movie you get some really cool action sequences but they are undercut by issues with pacing. A good part of it is shot very well but feels undercut by those doing the colour grading.

The short runtime means plenty of the actors are left with little or not enough to do and doesn't allow us to feel the characters the actors are working hard to flesh out.

I will argue that Steppenwolf was appropriately the right villain for this movie but it felt like the whole team missed an opportunity to do more with an interesting character. Instead of a character hell bent on revenge with the potential to unleash devastation on the world we are instead left with a disgraced but powerful, snarky coward.

The movie could have benefitted from the energy of original composer Junkie XL score to add a real sense of electronic rock'n roll to proceedings. Danny Elfman does a serviceable job under the circumstances but his classic approach leaves it feeling a bit too theatrical for my liking.

I mean don't get me wrong there were some parts of the movie I really liked but the story but the desire to lighten proceedings in the hopes of box office appeal really undercut the hard work of everyone working on that film that hoped to realise a grand vision.

Instead of a grand chapter we were ultimately left with what felt like an extended episode of a TV series.

To Geoff Johns and Warner Bros this movie should serve as proof that pandering to "fans" on discussion boards can undercut your efforts, leave you lacking direction and ultimately leave true fans respecting you less.

Good...not Marvel good, not Nolan good, not old school Tim Burton good, not classic Superman good...but good.  The BAD: pouty Lois Lane, awkward moments, lame villain. The GOOD: Superman's return is less brooding and more return to optimistic form. Aquaman is cooler than his previous incarnations, the Flash...is...ok, and Cyborg is pretty spot on....even got in a Booyah! Affleck's Batman could have used a bit more grit he was more convincing actually in BvS but I put that more on the change in tone of the film than on Affleck.  Lastly, Wonder Woman is Wonder Woman...she kicks butt and all the men cheer.  Sadly the film doesn't have the depth (really for any of these characters) that her stand-alone title does but she already is a strong established character and nothing changes in this film with her.  
So good but could have been a lot better like the plot to Injustice or the hit animated show.  Oh silly Hollywood.

Disclaimer: All opinions expressed are that of my own after viewing the film and is not to be taken as insult to any fans, or persons in association with the film. This review is met to summarize personal views, help movie goers decide on how to spend their time, and even help enlighten creatives with structural judgement to form into educational intake. This is not a professional review and is met to reflect on my opinion as the audience. Any opposing or agreeing views are encouraged to be expressed in their own posts to further conversations amongst movie lovers.  

PLOT: Though the plot isn't the original and unique materspiece film lovers greatly anticipate, it is reasonably presented and supported to be engaging enough.


CHARACTERS: The Flash-Batman relationship can't seem to present itself as anything but a clear attempt at a Spiderman-Ironman interaction, and this is assisted by Barry's overall personality being a straining effort to compete with Peter Parker featured in Spiderman: Homecoming. I actually do hate to compare Marvel and DC when trying to seperate the two in terms of legacy and creativity, but it's so hard to do so when it's obvious the franchises can't seem to stay away from each other, with these types of intentions being an plain example. Other fan favorites that seemed to be promising enough to get fans into theaters turned out to be water-down versions of the characters we loved and hope to see again unless the franchise continues down its current path.

DIALOGUE: With some cleverly written dialogue that greatly supports certain tones when needed, the domination of forced one-liners and forgettable exchanges help crumble the already rocky film.

PERFORMANCES: Though the film is filled with a talented cast, it's unclear if some of these mediocre performances were at the fault of a weak script, poor direction, or just lack of interest. The performance by Ezra Miller in particular was reasonably convincing at times, though what dominated his screen time was filled with overacting or lack of reacting.


ACTION: The fight scenes are filled with nothing spectacular or things that are unfamiliar to preceding action films. Filled with unnecessarily frequent slow-motion shots, crashing into concerte, one-liners, and WWE style combat, these battle scenes are just too unrealistic even with the acception of a being fantasy-based superhero movie. The larger battle scenes and climax especially rely too heavily on explosions and sound effects to win over viewers. Of course these things are expected for action films and can actually be effective, but the mark was missed with this film as this is a great example of giving viewers what they already know in hopes of it working again.

SPECIAL EFFECTS: Throughout the film, the effects are outstanding with it's budget, time, and attention to detail being very clearly presented. The environments and surrounds throughout the film are successful in rendering thoughts of the unique and abstract world of we have associated with DC, yet some of these effects can sometimes come across as standard video game like animation. 

MUSIC/SCORE: Being an admirer of Danny Elfman, I especially enjoyed his work on this film which perfectly captured the mood of individual scenes, and the overall tone of the film. What's also appreciated is how the music blends swiftly with the scene and characters, with the Flash's familiar theme during some of his focused screen time being a prime example.  

FINAL THOUGHTS: Though this is an improvement from recent DC films that presents to fans something imaginative and engaging, it's clear that the franchise has a couple of steps to go before again reaching the legacy that it has made itself known to have. In conclusion, LEGO Batman certainly tops this one.

If this film had come out around 10 years ago I would have appreciated it (slightly) more. Justice League's main problem is that it is simply dull fun. The cast is mostly likeable, however, with the numerous reshoots many characters are left with little development, namely newcomers Jason Momoa's Aquaman and Ezra Miller's Flash. The Russo's managed to introduce Spider-Man in a handful of minutes and yet this film leaves its audience with virtually no investment in any of its newcomers. The films third-act also feels rushed with many character conflicts being resolved without any explanation. The action and CGI is (for the most part) very good, as expected from the films gargantuan budget. And, as said before, the cast interactions are the best part of the film. However, the films central plot doesn't do its characters justice and leaves many conflicts and arcs incomplete with its rushed third act.

(Non-Spoiler Review). Incredibly disappointing. Believe it or not, I was excited for his film. I thought Wonder Woman was pretty good (minus the third act) and I assumed that Dc was getting better. Turns out that I was wrong unfortunately. First of all, the cgi is god awful, and it doesn't help that the movie opens up with a shot of Superman and his awful cgi chin. Secondly, all of the new characters that were introduced felt incredibly underdeveloped. Their introductions were all swift and half-assed. Third of all, there are plenty of other errors, like there's one scene where Cyborg's self defense system suddenly goes off, but there has been no indication that Cyborg ever has this ability. It's also never used again. Another one is when Wonder Woman was seen moving faster than a speeding bullet to save civilians, but then she was as slow as a regular person in during the rest of the movie. Fourth, they made Superman too strong. Superman basically defeats the main villain by himself! What's even the point of the Justice League when Superman completely dominates everybody? Not to mention that Batman was completely useless in this movie. Lastly, the plot was generic. It was basically The Avengers plot, but a lot worse. Steppenwolf's motivations are generic, his army of throw away aliens are generic (at least Infinity War's throw away army was interesting, since they were literally killing the selves to get through a force field.

TL;DR:  This movie had horrible cgi, forced introductions to the new characters, continuity errors, and making Superman seem like he doesn't need the Justice League.

For all the hate it got, there was a lot I actually liked about Batman V. Superman.  Sure it had some really low lows, but its highs were high enough that overall I found myself liking the movie.  Justice League however, is more like a consistent tone of meh.  It's not that bad I guess, but nothing about it is particularly good.
There are things in it I did like.  The casting is all really good first of all, and when the team is together playing off of each other they are enjoyable.  A standout for me was Flash.  He's not the Flash as we've typically seen him, he's more the bright-eyed youngster of the group who's still learning his powers, but I liked him.  Affleck is still good as Batman, though not as much a standout as in BvS, and Henry Cavill finally feels like a pure good-hearted Superman in this one.  The only role that felt a little off to me was J.K. Simmons as Jim Gordon, mostly because I so identify him with angry characters I kept expecting him to chew out Batman and demand pictures of Spider-Man or something.  He does his best, but he's not in the movie much, and never given a chance to do much.
What I didn't like about the movie?  Oh god...I really wanted to like this movie.  Every time a new thing would happen, I would perk up and think "oh, I wonder how this will go?" and then I would get mad or disappointed.  Going to Atlantis?  Oh, it looks like crap.  Introducing the villain?  Oh, he's just some bland BS.  Big action sequence?  Oh, just a bunch of CGI nonsense.  The CGI in this movie in particular is just awful.  I never felt like I was looking at anything real, it just felt like a video game cut-scene, and not even a good video game, but like a low-rent Xbox 360 game.  The story is fairly straightforward, moreso than BvS anyway, but it's just not that interesting.  It feels rushed, and because most of these characters are getting introduced in this movie it feels like the cliff notes version of a larger story.  I would say that maybe they needed more time, but I've seen animated Justice League movies that are able to introduce their characters, give them a threat, and provide a solid story in roughly 70 minutes.  Having said that, DC's animated game is killing it right now, just stick with that.
If this movie had come out 20 or even 10 years ago, it would have been passable.  It wouldn't have been great, but compared to the superhero game of the time it would have been considered pretty good.  Now, the bard has been raised so high, something like this just can't compete.  It has no real identity beyond playing catch up and trying to do what it thinks people want, which just gives it an identity crisis.  My rating honestly is probably a bit harsher than it should be here.  The thing is, there is stuff in this movie I did like, there were little sparks of hope and little moments where I realized they were headed in the right direction.  But the end result is just so jumbled and ugly that I really can't recommend it.  I was so consistently annoyed my whole time watching the movie.  I kept thinking it would turn around, but then something would piss me off.  A couple of brilliant moments can't make up for that.

I had a lot of fun with this movie. Sure, it has its flaws, including the very questionable CGI mouth of Superman, but I still enjoyed it. I just wish it wasn't rushed into production, like many of the other DC films, just so they can keep in competition the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

I'm a huge fan of DC, but honestly, WHAT WERE THEY THINKING? "A movie can only be as good as its villain." Thats an old saying, and its almost always true. I mean, who in the world even is Steppenwolf? They have this great villain named Darkseid. But who should we use? Some new guy nobody knows and that nobody cares about. Also, it made me frustrated how Batman struggled to defeat one bug creature, when in reality, he's one of the most talented martial artists on the face of the earth. Seemed like he was useless, and didn't come up with any brilliant plans. Plus, Cyborg was supposed to be funny but really wasn't, and Aquaman should be a super hardcore, deadly hero, but seemed like the blonde hair orange outfit surfer dude we're used to. Wonder woman also wasn't as good as she was in her own movie. It really felt like the only good hero was the flash, who was actually funny. However, with all of this negativity from me, I am eager to see the second one, as long as they get a better villain.

The villain was the only negative point of an otherwise brilliant movie. They dealt with Superman's return perfectly, effectively showed him as the best of the Justice League members, and perfectly set up the much more serious threats lying ahead. This was just a preview, and I expect future villains to be well-planned.

I honestly didn't expect the characters to mingle and interact as well as they did. Everyone had a relationship with everyone, and you could tell that there might be potential future rifts in play, particularly with Aquaman. Cyborg, a hero I was never a fan of, was much better portrayed here.

The ode to the Flash vs Superman race at the end was classic. As was Lex Luthor losing his hair and becoming a bit more serious and less erratic than we saw in BvS. If DC keep playing it like this, the character progression will be clear to see by the next few movies.

Batman dominates with his rich toy vehicle and aircraft both luxury and invention that makes up his lack of superhuman powers. All the other heroes have their brief life backgrounds. Cinematography is a memory collection of artistic scenes probably too brief to be remembered or be discovered such as the geometry shapes of building structures. The villain is like some Thor copycat villain from a Thor movie with Hulk-like invincible features, probably thrilling to first-time teenager but not to a middle-aged adult like myself who thinks that the villain is half badass.

I don't believe this movie deserves the hate it got. I think this is the second best movie in the DCEU, behind Wonder Women. This movie is much more fun than the previous entrees in this universe. This team-up movie, while not being on the same level as 'Marvel's The Avengers', gives us fun action sequences, a lot more quips than previous films and a few great performances. The problems I had with this movie included some of the visual effects were extremely cartoony at times, a villain that does not seem threatening and has an incredibly weak backstory and some of the characters in the 'Justice League' are not given their rightful amount of backstory and screen time. Excluding those flaws, I had a good time in the theater when I reminded myself that I wasn't going to get another great superhero movie, I was going to get a mostly-fun action film.

I saw this for the first time during the same week I watched Avengers: Infinity War.  I am a DC fan (superheroes, comics), but there is simply no comparison between these two films.  JL is a mess.  Thin character development, tired dialogue, a wholly one-dimensional plot and - this cannot be overstated - appalling CGI.  The villain is so cartoonish that it is all but impossible to suspend disbelief long enough to find him in any way threatening.  The cast does what they can with what they've been given, but it is rarely enough to raise the film above mediocrity.  If DC is going to keep this franchise going, they need new leadership and an entirely new vision for presenting these characters and stories.  Jenkins' WW was a great start - it is crazy to think, after that example, that they would release this garbage.

What DC did wrong that Marvel did right was rush it. Marvel allowed us to get emotionally attached to these characters making it to where, even in The Avengers, made us excited. We knew yes, a good bit of stuff about Superman and Diana, but that wasn't enough. Yes, the Flash was comedic, and yes, that was NOT what I thought of when I thought about when I think Aquaman or Cyborg. Finally, Batman. In BvS, Zack casted Batman into a dark light, brooding and fueled by rage, but this movie gave Bruce more of a light, funny tone, which is just not Batman. Overall, yes it was an okay movie and, no, I'm not a critic, but the movie just felt rushed.

I think this film would probably get a lot more hate if ANYBODY even had the energy to care about it at this point. What should have been the shining moment in DC's movie universe instead just turned out a fat nothing. Sure, a couple of the scenes were cool (Superman's revival was awesome, even if a bit dumb), but overall the plot was boring, the villain was boring, the quips were more annoying than endearing, and the whole thing didn't even have the visuals to back it up. Walking the line between poorly executed and straight-up bad.

While DC's Justice League was an entertaining flick to watch at 1 am at night, it definitely had several flaws which could have easily been prevented. So much for surprising us if Superman was going to live, they put Henry Cavil's name in the opening sequence! Dunces. And about the opening sequence, with the children filming Superman....talk about Super-lame! Barry Allen's (the flash) jokes had my buddy laughing out loud, however for me the most i got out of his jokes were a few chuckles and a sour taste in my mouth. They tried too hard to make Barry Allen relatable with his ability to be a "snackhole" and eat a ton of pizza. Pizza, aha! Another aggravating factor was the fact that Batfleck just did not do it for me. Batman is not the Christian Bale version. Cold and calculating? I think not, he went into his missions without a definite plan, and relied on his instinct, and kept getting his ass beat. Not the Batman i remember. However, the movie did have redeeming qualities. Wonder Woman, aqua man , and cyborg were all done very well, and I enjoyed the characters powers and abilities. Gal gadot is so hot and I would let her freely play with my ***hole. The movie was entertaining, and the fight scenes were pretty epic. What the hell was with that janitor? Very unnecessary and forced! Batman's lair is another plus for the movie, and there seems to be a lot of water that seeps into the bat cave (aqua man must love it!). Overall, this movie is a 6.5/10, but I will not likely be watching it anytime soon or ever again! Thanks!

Justice League (2017) tried to be a lighthearted superhero film, but by a single bound, it breaks its bones so badly. The plot is just a rehash of the one from Man Of Steel (2013), most of the action sequences suck, the acting has become tiresome, the direction by both Zack Snyder and Joss Whedon are pretty lame, the writing and the humor are awful, the effects are horrible, the villain is incredibly under-developed and stupid, and the entire film is lame. The score, at times, is bad, but there are instances where it does hit on the right note. It is the complete antithesis of what I love about superheroes and a huge injustice to the league itself. This movie has failed to make me pledge my allegiance to the DCEU, which has been a failure of a franchise since day one. In agreement with OcpCommunications, just stick with the Justice League animated series from 2001 and Justice League Unlimited and avoid this pile of kryptonite shards. Hell, I will gladly watch Justice League: The New Frontier (2007) and Justice League: The Flashpoint Paradox (2013) a billion times more over this. This is one of the worst comic book films and the worst DCEU film to date.

Justice League (2017) is entertaining at times, but its uninspired set-piece battles and cheap-looking visual effects result in a detached and passable experience. In addition, the film does so little to deeply engage with its legendary comic book heroes and the conflict falls flat with its underwhelmingly one-dimensional villain, Steppenwolf. The lack of proper setup for the upcoming world-ending threat leaves Bruce Wayne, jarringly and annoyingly, monologuing about "enemies from far away" as he assembles a group of random superhumans to fight for humanity's existence. Wonder Woman is easily the best member of the team, but the frequent sexualization of the character dilutes everything that Patty Jenkins has strongly established in her film. Danny Elfman's score is good, yet nothing special or memorable. I expected more from a film with such a huge budget and an incredibly talented cast. An injustice towards the Justice League.

I was surprised that I enjoyed this movie as much as I did. I felt like the plot was weak and unimaginative. The Actors (except Flash) carried it for me. I say this a lot and I stand by it, but the problem with some comic book movies is that they are often only as good as their villains and there was nothing particularly interesting about this villain which kinda hurt the movie.

Okay, I just want to say this first before I go critical. I'm a fan of DC comics. I truly am. Batman and Superman are one of the first superheroes I grew up with. However, when it comes to Warner Bros' own "DC Universe", I'm not a big fan of and this film proves why. "Justice League" is a hot mess that can't make up what it wants to be. It's CGI action sequences came out from a PS2 game and storyline is almost similar to Marvel's "The Avengers." It's definitely more lighter and vibrant than it's previous counterparts, but did it really need to be? Did it really have to be another Marvel clone? In order to make a successful franchise, you have to make sure it is distinguishable from the others. Not play the copy cats. Batman was truly godawful in this. It's in no way Ben Affleck's fault . It's the fault of the filmmakers and the head of the studio who doesn't seem to understand the source material that these characters have come from. Plus hiring Joss Whedon to fix the mistakes made by Zack Snyder was a bad choice. He's a decent writer, but he has a bad habit of writing force humor and creating films that seem to be made for television. I believe a reboot is in order?

Justice League Review (SPOLIER-FREE) 

PROS:
1. The character designs were good (ONLY when it came to the heroes) Not mind-blowing but not bad either.
2. Compared to Suicide Squad, it's a LOT better in regards to being watchable.
3. It does end.

CONS:
1. The villain and his design were bloody atrocious. I'm sorry but if I can't remember his name HALF-WAY while I'm watching the movie and his design looks as if the ugliest monster you can think of from Dark Souls and Diablo had a baby and then turned the graphics down to PS1 quality (even saying it's PS1 quality is generous), then you know you have screwed up.
2. The CGI made me feel almost physically sick. This movie makes Wonder Woman's CGI look comparable to the CGI in the Planet Of The Ape Reboot Trilogy. This movie makes the Scorpion King in the Mummy 2 look photo-realistic. OH, I am NOT taking that back.
3. The tone of this movie is really, really bad. DC was trying so hard to be like marvel that in the end, it made Justice League look hilarious, in all the wrong ways. Suppressing laughter throughout the serious parts of this movie was almost impossible for me. Jokes didn't fall flat on their face in this movie because they did land... on a floor of razor sharp spikes.
4. Aquaman and Flash are as funny as the live action Smurfs movie. If you haven't seen the live action Smurfs, don't.
5. Superman can be better portrayed by a rock with an S carved into it. 
6. "S" doesn't stand for "Hope". But I know one word it stands for which best describes this movie.
7. Although it's only 2 hours, it felt like more. A LOT MORE.
8. Every character in this movie (whether good or bad) has extremely unlikeable and unrealistic behaviour. 
9. The story, the acting and the dialogue is so bad that a poorly-written fanfiction would have more to offer.
10. I can probably come up with more but these are the ones that came on top of my head and we would be here for a while if I tried to list every last thing wrong with this movie.

IN CONCLUSION:
DC's extended universe, in my eyes, has failed exponentially. Each movie get's worse and worse. Currently, there are 5 DCEU movies. 1 of which is actually good (Wonder Woman), 1 of which is OK but not brilliant(Man Of Steel) and then you have BvS, you have Suicide Squad and then you have this. DC needs to cancel the DCEU. I'm not saying they need to stop making movies entirely, what I'm saying is that they need to try going in the direction they went with before with the Dark Knight. Focus on making a good movie that can stand out on its own rather than a movie that is only there to reference and fore-shadow later movies. Hell, Wonder Woman proved they can do this really well so just go in that direction. If they take this route, it can lead to a brighter future for DC.

This movie get's an F. Hopefully my next review won't be about something as bad as this.

Justice League is a fun, non risky, movie with linear and easy to follow story. 
The story goes as follows, an ancient alien conqueror called Steppenwolf visited earth a long long time ago to, well, conquer it with the help of his army of parademons and his three teraforming devices called motherboxes but was defeated by the alliance of men, atlantians and amazons. Each tribe took one of the boxes for safe guarding. Now after the death of Superman,  Steppenwolf has returned to recover his boxes and finish the job.
First let's talk about the pros of the movie. Most of the cinematography is great to watch, especially when the awfully bad CGI reshoots are absent. The heroes have a fluent enough chemistry, for a first team up, and they were all portrayed adequately by their casting choices ( except for Batman and Superman, because sometimes they felt like completely different characters to BvS). The fights were very good with some good choreography when it came to wonder Woman. Flash's use of the speed force was top notch and gave his powers a certain feel we've long wanted for our scarlet speedster. Superman's resurrection was handled pretty well and his fights with and against the team were amazing. Cyborg acted both as a heroe and a plot device for the movie and his role I think was the most important next to the trinity. His CGI, contrary to common opinion, was fantastic as well as his weaponry.  And finally the backstory of Steppenwolf was shown excellently and on point, considering it was his first appearance ever on screen, and covered everything a non fan needed to know to follow the movie. His strikes when he was fighting felt powerful and you could feel how threatening he was. Especially when he was threatening and killing civilians and Amazons. 
Now about the cons. First of all, the reshoots and the CGI in them where horribly noticeable and drew you away from the consistency of the film. Speaking of consistency, the whole feel of the movie made like it wasn't a continuation of the previous instalments in the DCEU which ruined most of the backstory, in a way. Another problem of the movie was the overused humour. I know superhero movies are supposed to be fun but not necessarily funny, and certainly not when it comes to the end of the world and extinction of the human kind. Also, humour is not suitable for some characters like batman, who are sacrastic and cocky at best. Batman in BvS was an old, broken down Bruce Wayne, adrift from his moral code, all around a brutal murdering machine. But in this movie his throwing jokes, enjoys the return of superman like they were old pals and can't keep up in a fight with ONE parademon. It was disappointing at best. Aquaman on the other hand, while he was badass, he felt a bit underused. With his powers being limited only to super strength in action. His trident was used only once and in order to stop a flood( pretty basic if you ask me). The Flash was a bit irritating at times but I could get by that considering he is just a kid figuring out his powers. Steppenwolf, when his design is taken into account, I think was pretty lame. Wearing some kind of medieval armour, yeeeah what an alien look(Sarcasm).
Overall, Justice League was a mediocre super hero movie and not as terrible as some will tell you it was. It's definitely worth watching as it is fun and fast paced in its combat sequences. What makes it feel bad for some people is the constant comparison with its elseworld counterpart, The Avengers, which was set up in a lot of previous films, so we were familiar with the characters and the villain's full backstory. Try viewing Justice League with an open mind and you'll have a fun time for sure.

I did like it, but it was no where better than The Avengers. Here's what they did wrong! 1. Aquaman, The Flash, and Cyborg didn't even get there own solo movie yet to introduce them to become a team. 2. Superman got brought back to life in a wrong way. 3. A lot of scenes that were in the trailers were cut out in the movie. And 4. Villain wasn't really terrifying.

The Justice League had some pretty big shoes to fill, not because Marvel's Avengers 2012 pretty much defined the big screen superhero team-up, but because the Justice League were the first to do it in the comics. Despite strong performances from Gadot, Affleck and Momoa, the result was slightly disappointing. The CGI on Cyborg looked cheap, Ezra Miller's portrayal of Barry Allen was awkward and the directing overall needed a little more work done. DC's Arrowverse TV shows some how did the impossible by outshining the film universe on all grounds, especially Barry Allen. Ezra Miller was trying too hard to be funny, blame the script, but it wasn't working. Also, considering how popular Grant Gustin has become in the Arrowverse's version of the The Flash, i don't see why the DCEU hasn't followed the MCU's steps in the inclusion of the TV shows. In short, Ezra Miller's version of Barry Allen/The Flash can't catch up to Grant Gustin's Arrowverse version. And lastly, Superman's resurrection was predictable, so it should've happened earlier in the film, or even squeezed into the ending of Batman Vs Superman. That being said, the visuals were mostly good, the action was excellent and that Batmobile was gorgeous!

After reading and hearing about the countless ridiculous production issues this project had, seeing it for myself was extremely depressing.

So what did we get after this clusterfuck of a production?

Laughable, bland, cheap-looking CGI that you'd expect out of a much smaller scale movie.

Bland, cheap TV show quality cinematography and framing that absolutely do not fit anywhere near the scale of the characters on screen (fat batman rolling around on fake grass).

A barely noticeable soundtrack with only the slightest hints of character, which were also only remnants of previous, better suited composers.

Extremely amateurish and lazy characterization moments, combined with some very flat and lazy "funny" moments.

The movie also severely lacked a sense of coherence and unity. It felt spliced together with a lot of vital mood and transition scenes missing. It's also really telling that the movie is exactly 2 hours long. This point ties back to the infamous production issues and studio meddling. It felt like a void husk of what was meant to be.

The actors themselves barely got time to breathe, and when they did have the lonely little crammed characterization scene, it looked like they struggled to work with what they got. It was sad to witness.

So, all these bare minimum parts add up to one ultimately sad end product. It's like they already committed to doing this movie, already begun production and were legally obliged to see it to the end, despite every important part of the production failing or getting ruined or meddled with. This is Sunk Cost: The Movie. I wish they'd just halt production and postpone it whatever year they'd deem necessary, but obviously it's too much to ask from an incompetent studio like WB.

Before we begin, this movie is horrible, there. Zack Snyder or Joss Whedon's 'Justice League' is the ultimate build up to the 6 heroes coming together, 3 of which were set up, the other 3 not at all. The characters relationships work, however that's the only thing that works in this dumpster fire. Aquaman is a bland character and is very unlikable anytime he is on screen, to make up for this he makes jokes that don't land and does some 'badass' stuff, like hitting the cgi villian Steppenwolf. Batman does a complete 360 and changes from a brooding dark basically murderous vigilante to a jokey Tony Stark type figure. It doesn't help that Ben Affleck looks barely awake throughout the course of this film. Wonder Woman is just as boring and 1 dimensional as she was in 2016's 'Dawn of Justice' with only her solo movie providing any reason to care, the countless references to Steve Trevor annoyingly remind us that we could be watching a better movie. Ezra Miller's the Flash is an attempt to recreate essentially Spider-man, removing any intelligence that the character previously had, in place for a quirky, constantly messing up Flash, purely for comedic relief. Cyborg is bland and one of the few interesting characters that the movie refuses to explore. The film has awful writing with jokes that almost never land, and a plot that is so generic and straightforward that it just makes you realize the best thing about this movie. It's so straightforward and generic that you can watch it as just a dumb superhero popcorn flick. This film is unintentionally funny, and looks ugly compared to Snyder's usual beautiful style, the cgi is awful with some shots I can compare to that of the Injustice games and the main villain Steppenwolf who appears as a Playstation character. The effects are awful, references to Wonder Woman that are shoehorned in, no consistency in this cinematic universe, and a film ugly to look at. However this film is dumb-fun and feels like a Saturday morning cartoon special and I had fun watching it.

Ya know... I actually liked this movie. I can't say it's a GOOD movie, but c'mon, it's fun! It's not as good as "Wonder Woman" but it's leagues (heh) better than that piece of shit "Batman vs Superman"... that movie causes me pain by its mere existence. Yes, it's rampant with the same plot inconsistencies that plague nearly every superhero movie, but the ensemble worked and the film does a decent job of setting things up for what's to come in the DC Extended Universe... though its desperation to keep up with Marvel is palpable. The characters were fun, if underdeveloped, and I found all of them to be at least marginally interesting. The exception to this is the Batfleck - I guess it's a testament to how bad BvS was that he was the best thing about that movie, since he is the worst thing about this one. He needs to take a page from Lego Batman's book and learn how to lighten up already! Gal Godot brings the same tenacious spirit to Wonder Woman as she did in her solo outing, and the new recruits are all worthy additions. I liked Cyborg better than I thought I would, and Jason Momoa (sploosh!) was perfectly cast as a modernized, supercool Aquaman... though he didn't play as big of a role as I would have liked and was pretty much a non-entity in this film. But the absolute scene-stealer of this movie is Ezra Miller as The Flash... gimme more of that guy! He is definitely the best part of the movie, thanks to his impeccable comic timing and the eager energy he brings not only to the character, but to the whole team. As much as I love to see Wonder Woman finding her footing as a leader, he really is what makes this team click. The villain was decent with just the right amount of menace - formidable enough where one of our heroes could not have defeated him solo, but not too formidable that he can just squish them all into dust. He's a suitable foil for our novice heroes, it's just too bad that he looks so lame... when he shows up, it's like a cartoon wandered onto the set. Not that that is any different than the rest of the film. I get that a movie like this is going to be CGI-heavy, but damn, there is hardly any actual footage in the whole movie. To make matters worse, some of the CGI is, like, really really bad. That greenscreen... yikes. Anyway, it's over the top and silly and borrows too heavily from Marvel, but it's still a good time. Just sit back and enjoy, and don't think about it too much.

If there was justice in the world, no one would have made:
JUSTICE LEAGUE
Dogs, one of the purest and most fascinating animals in nature, can sometimes learn a trick after a fairly limited amount of tries and can learn to never repeat a bad deed after some constructive correction. DC is like Patrice's dumb dog who won't stop peeing on the carpet despite being taught not to a bazillion times. How can you entrust a movie that was supposedly pivotal to the foundation on your entire cinematic universe on the hands of someone who consistently produces poor movies for you? Despite the critic and fan backlash, wouldn't you learn to change and tell Zack Snyner to go do overstylized gladiator movies? Yeah, Marvel is stuck on a formula but at least it's one from which good movies come out of. Justice League is a boring mess that neither keeps you much entertained nor does anything remotely out of the box. Its attention to detail is next to zero, there is only one shot that is to my fancy mainly because the other 900 are just a swamp of CGI with no support in prodigious framing. What's more, and I have to hammer down this nail again, a hero is only as strong as its antagonist whomever or whatever that might be. A flat tyre, a business competitor or even a psychological constraint that won't allow him or her to move forward. But an antagonist like Steppenwolf is like making an inanimate chair as the movie's enemy. It isn't enough, specially in a world where every main character is invincible due to a producer's lack of balls to kill anyone important (DC isn't even brave enough not to have the last shot of BvS with dirt levitating signalling that Superman's alive. They don't know anything about suspense!). Also, the script is your husband's encounter with that hooker which will give you the ultimate reason to end your long and unloving relationship. Look, no matter what you think, you can't make a movie good when the only way you cut through scenes is by quippy one-liners that are total unnatural to actual human speech! There has to be so much more like the attention to how bits work together within a scene and within the entirety of the movie; ow characters can interact without the sole use of expositional or "funny" dialogue; And don't take me as a purist, I watch all of what cinema has to offer from the smallest indie to the biggest blockbuster but Justice League is the last time I said "wait a minute, guys, DC might just learn from its mistakes and turn things around". No, you shouldn't spend your money watching this movie and no, you shouldn't buy a ticket to the DCEU until they prove they can make above-average movies.

This was my type of Super Hero movie. Simple, straightforward plot without much social nonsens and preaching. Little in terms of the all too common whining and sel pitying by the heroes. On Wikipedia you can read that the movie was criticized for its "overuse of CGI". Well, go watch another movie then for Christ sake! News Flash: It is a Super Hero movie! There are supposed to be a shitload of CGI in a super hero movie. Personally I enjoyed every second of the FX loaded scenes.

I liked all the heros in this movie. The Flash was a bit silly at times but it was bearable. Gal Gadot is as hot (I had to say it) as ever as Wonder Woman. There are a few comical moments but luckily they are not overdone. Aquaman accidentally sitting on Wonder Woman's "truth lasso" was quite hilarious actually.

The SF was generally great. I really liked the explosive action scenes. The colorful tendrils that invaded the land around Steppenwolf's lair was a bit si-so though. They should have kept them just black and red at least.
Steppenwolf himself was okay. From a distance he was pretty great but up close (and there was really too many up close scenes of him) he looked...not so great, especially when talking.

There are a couple of stupid faults of course. Usually involving the good guys just standing around looking while the bad guy screws them. Leaving the, obviously, all important third mother box unguarded and the lust looking stupid when Steppenwolf grabbed it was a real low.

Anyway, I really liked this movie. I do hope we get more like it.

By the way, this is obviously another movie were we see how crappy rotten tomatoes official scoring and their so called "CRITICS" ARE!.

Better than I expected it to be. Is it entertaining? To some degree, yes. It was pretty fun to see the new characters being introduced, showcasing some interaction between them and the ones we already know (including a little humour here and there), as well as seeing them test their abilities on the (unimpressive) enemy. But was it good? Sadly, no. Everything that was wrong with DC's previous efforts (excluding the excellent 'Wonder Woman') is still very much wrong here, just to a lesser extent. I don't know when or if the studio will learn that it's not all about VFX (hell, there was only a couple of scenes where things actually looked real) and throwing as much messy action at the audience as possible; that characters and their development -- the weight that gives a story -- actually matters, but when they do, they could start to bring together something great. 'Justice League' feels like a small step in the right direction (I'm sure that's mostly Whedon's doing), but there's still a long way to go. Perhaps there is some hope yet now that Snyder's time seems to have come to an end.

I had to create an account to write a review just for this movie.  All the negativity towards this picture is unjustified. I thought it was well written and it really grabs ahold of it's audience and keeps them captivated. This is the first time these hero's have ever shared a screen together in a live action movie and that wasn't easy to do. That alone should not serve as an excuse for liking the film, but the content was well worth the price of admission. Snyder does a great job blending the different characters personas together nicely without overdoing one over the others.  The flash is hilarious and putting him along side Aquaman and Batman is perfect. I felt it was a huge step up from the mediocre BvS that failed to please most of it's audience's. I know I'll be watching my copy multiple times until darkseid is unleashed. I also look forward to the stand alone films that hopefully stay on track as long as the executives at WB stay out of the way.

Coming into Justice League, I really wanted to dampen my expectations. Not because I thought it was going to be bad, only because I didn't want to be disappointed. Yet when sitting in front of the big screen with my popcorn, I couldn't help but get extremely excited for what I was about to see. By the end, was I disappointed? I could not have been further away from disappointed, I was amazed at just how good it was.

We start off with Batman doing Batman things and what looks like just taking down a criminal. However this served as an introduction to the story and seeing our first parademon. I'm going to say this a lot, but I was worried about what the parademons would be like but they were designed very well. It was a great start seeing Batman climb over buildings and backflipping off a water tower to take down the criminal. It's something we have never really seen from a cinematic Batman and it was all done so well, that it was believable. If I hadn't caught myself on, I would have applauded Ben Affleck for being so agile.

Moving at an excellent pace through out, the movie then gives us the reminder we need with Wonder Woman. Diana rescues a batch of hostages by quite brilliantly blocking every bullet from a machine gun and taking down all the bad guys. It reminded us of the strength of Wonder Woman but also that she is some what active in being a superhero. Of course she's not the only Amazonian left. We go back to Themyscira and see Queen Hippolyta have warriors guarding one of the mother boxes. This is when we see our first arrival of Steppenwolf (more on him later). There were some really great set pieces with the Amazonians showing their skill with the sword and bow and arrow but ultimately Steppenwolf gets the mother box and Queen Hippolyta lights the beacon. This beacon signals to Wonder Woman an invasion is coming.

Wonder Woman and Batman team up and agree a team needs put together, however not before we see the history of Steppenwolf trying to destroy earth before, but failing because of the Atlanteans, Amazonians and mankind teaming up. As well as an awesome cameo from a green lantern in battle, dying and their ring zipping off to find the next worthy lantern, very cool.

Aquaman, the Flash and Cyborg all are recruited but it isn't rushed and each character gets their character arc fleshed out. Of course a stand alone movie would have really gave each a proper origin story, but we still got enough to really understand each character. Cyborg began a little dull, but the more we understood, the more it made sense and how he's trying to understand and control with what's happening to him. Same with The Flash and how he's not a criminal analyst yet and is still trying to fully control his powers. This is shown by him being clumsy and really brings his human qualities across. This makes both characters very relatable, even though they are both superheroes.

Aquaman is no different as he is dealing with not feeling part of his world and not stepping up to rule Atlantis. This is also the first time we see Atlantis and underwater scenes. These were beautiful and the 'underwaterness' was very effective. The Queen Mera cameo added to Aquaman's backstory and all together, has got me very excited to see more in the Aquaman movie. Through this scene we get to see Steppenwolf steal the 2nd mother box and then Cyborg revealing he has the 3rd, this is where things get really interesting.

Batman has the idea that Superman could be brought back to life using the power of the mother box. It's really interesting seeing the dynamic between Batman and Wonder Woman and the conflict between them in whether it's right to bring back Superman. The way in which they brought Superman back was very satisfying and made sense for the story. Clark not realising where he was at first and trying to come to terms with being alive again was great to watch. Fighting the Justice League, The Flash realising Superman could move at his speed, and Clark asking Batman, do you bleed, all awesome and intense scenes. Batman using Lois as his 'big weapon' was great and a payoff from the Flash dream sequence from Batman vs Superman.

The team find Steppenwolf about to destroy the world and of course save the world, with the help of Superman really proving how strong and indestructible he is. It really was great seeing the whole team fighting together and the shot of all 6 standing after defeating Steppenwolf is just a comic book dream. I can't fault any part or character of the story, all had really strong arcs and were utilised in the best possible way. Except for one, and that was the movie's villain.

The decision to have Steppenwolf as full CG was a bit of a misstep in my eyes. The face animation wasn't the best I've ever seen and although he served his purpose, even justifying bringing back Superman, there was just no real sense of threat from the world ending. There was no panic in the streets, there were no city evacuations, and for the earth being minutes away from being destroyed, the League kept it pretty under wraps. Steppenwolf is far from a good villain but he isn't an awful one, and it doesn't take away from the story and the league at all.

With the tragic circumstances surrounding the departure of Zack Snyder, Joss Whedon stepped in and shot reportedly 20% of the movie. I can honestly say the whole movie was seamlessly edited together and never at one point did it feel like 2 movies or 2 directors' vision. Yes, you could see Whedon's humour and a few scenes but it worked. Most of the humour worked, was funny and wasn't too on the nose, some didn't quite land but that was fine.

The final thing to talk about is the 2 post credits scenes which were fantastic, 1 being a jaw dropper for me. The first one was more for the fans and the Flash and Superman about to race to see who the fastest man alive is, very cool. The 2nd one however, was unreal. At first I thought we were getting some silly Lex Luther in prison talking babble scene, but then seeing Deathstroke standing on that boat, he looks incredible. With Lex saying they need to set up their own league or sorts, it sets up all sorts of possibilities for the future.

DIAGNOSIS - INPATIENT CARE

Justice League
(2017)

Plot:
Fuelled by his restored faith in humanity and inspired by Superman's selfless act, Bruce Wayne enlists the help of his newfound ally, Diana Prince, to face an even greater enemy. Together, Batman and Wonder Woman work quickly to find and recruit a team of meta-humans to stand against this newly awakened threat. But despite the formation of this unprecedented league of heroes - Batman, Wonder Woman, Aquaman, Cyborg and The Flash - it may already be too late to save the planet from an assault of catastrophic proportions.

Review:
If this is DC's attempt to challenge Marvel, they done a very bad job! After the poor Batman vs. Superman, I thought that the DC comics production team would have gone back to the drawing board with this movie but they made another mediocre action flick, without giving any of the superheroes any depth. They really need to take a leaf out of Marvels book, by adding loads of humour, which seemed to work in the latest Thor movie, and Deadpool. With that aside, the action scenes were pretty impressive, and it was good to see the superheroes battling together but I still was expecting more from the first DC Justice League movie. Anyway, this film sees Batman (Ben Affleck), joining forces with Wonder Woman (Gal Gadot), to put together a superhero team to takedown the evil Steppenwolf (Ciaran Hinds), who is trying to gather 3 precious artefacts that are hidden on earth. After battling in Amazon, were Wonder Woman was born, Steppenwolf manages to retrieve the first box, so there leader, Queen Hippolyta (Connie Nielsen) sends a message to earth, hoping that Wonder Woman will know how much danger earth is in. After Batman tries to recruit Aquaman (Jason Momoa) to create a new super group, Steppenwolf steals the second artefact from the sea, which forces Aquaman to join forces with the others. Batman then recruits the Flash (Ezra Miller) and Cyborg (Ray Fisher), and they manage to find the 3rd artefact, which helps them to bring Superman back to life. Believe it or not! Anyway, with all of them on board, they put together a plan to kill Steppenwolf, who manages to steal the 3rd artefact from them but his powers are way too much for the Justice League. The storyline wouldn't have been too bad, if the characters had some form of a background, and I really didn't think that Ben Affleck played Batman that well, especially after Christopher Nolan's great interpretation of the superhero. The Flash also wasn't in the same league as Quicksilver, who has the same type of super powers, and the Cyborg and Aquaman could have been much better. Superman did show his true powers, when he was battling against his fellow team mates and Steppenwolf but I still think that the movie could have been much better if they added some decent wit. Anyway, I wasn't that impressed with the movie, and the ending, with Lex Luther and Deadshot, didn't make the next movie that promising. Average! 

Round-Up:
This movie was directed by Zack Snyder, 52, who also brought you Dawn of the Dead, the great 300, Watchmen, Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole, Sucker Punch, the poor Man Of Steel and Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice. As he was resposinsible for killing of Superman in Batman v Superman, I think that he realised that he made a big mistake, which is why he came up with that ridiculous resurrection in this movie. His poor storytelling methods destroyed the Superman franchise, and I'm surprised to see that he is returning to direct another Justice League movie, after this poor attempt. Audiences usually look forward to seeing a movie about the individual super heroes but I'm not that interested in seeing a film about any of the other Justice League, except for another Wonder Woman movie as the first one was quite entertaining. It will be interesting to see how they are going to introduce the Green Lantern, who was another important superhero in the Justice League but after the terrible job that they done with the movie starring Ryan Reynolds, they really need to give that character a serious reboot. There is rumours about an Aquaman movie later on this year, along with Shazam, with Dwayne Johnson playing the villain Black Adam. Later on next year there should be another Wonder Woman movie and Suicide Squad 2, which should hopefully be better than the first movie. Batman should also be making another stand alone movie, and Justice League Dark, Batgirl, Green Lantern Corps, The Flash: Flashpoint, Justice League 2, Cyborg, Nightwing, Man Of Steel 2, Gotham City Sirens, Deadshot, Black Adam and Sandman are also on the cards to boost the DC comic book movie franchise but as it takes so long for these movies to be produced, I doubt that I'll be alive to see them all.

Budget: $300million
Worldwide Gross: $658million

Genre: Action, Adventure, Fantasy
Cast: Ben Affleck, Henry Cavill, Amy Adams, Gal Gadot, Ezra Miller, Jason Momoa, Ray Fisher, Jeremy Irons, Diane Lane, Connie Nielsen, J.K. Simmons, Joe Morton, Amber Heard, Ciaran Hinds, David Thewlis and Michael EcElhatton. 5/10

It really is great to see these characters on screen, coming together and fighting a greater evil. There's some moments of pure magic that rank among my favourite in superhero movies. However it's also a very simple story, as is the resolution, that doesn't feel substantial enough for a property of the calibre of the Justice League. The storied production issues and writing changes are obvious throughout, with some shockingly unfinished cgi and tonal inconsistency with some of the reshot scenes and dialogue. it's shortened runtime doesn't give the 3 new heroes enough backstory for me, and it feels like there should be generally more to this film, but it's not on screen. Despite all that though it just about makes it through without tearing at the seams and coming apart entirely. It is no worse than some other superhero films i can think of and i would say it's worth a watch. Flawed but ultimately enjoyable.
On a personal note, I lament what it could have been. If you're hoping for a fitting follow up to the uncompromising vision of Man of Steel and Batman v Superman, you will be sorely disappointed. Take it for what it is however and you'll be able to enjoy it, hopefully.

So, it’s the fifth film of the DC Extended Universe, immediately following from Wonder Woman and Dawn of Justice and could it be their answer to the MCU’s Avengers? I do try to forget the MCU when watching these but it’s impossible to not draw comparisons, especially when you can see the influence and direct competition. It does make me wonder if I would like these more if the MCU’s success wasn’t apparent. Batfleck is haunted by a recurring threat coupled with his guilt of contributing to the death of Superman. He’s also got wind of a few other special individuals that might be able to aid his cause in defending the Earth, so he embarks on a mission to recruit Aquaman, The Flash, Cyborg and of course, the possible new favourite, Wonder Woman. Now, even with all these strong characters; the story and common enemy that brings them together is somewhat, underwhelming and pathetic. The script is totally cliched and is only forgiven because it’s essentially a comic book movie. It’s quite cheesy, especially in comparison to the previous movies, and there’s a clear influence from the MCU with the comedy elements that actually works. It had me laughing out loud. The CGI was quite weak, looking cheap but it did make the overall film more comical with over-the-top action that’s certainly up to par. I understand there was some required reshoots which must have put strain on the production, not to mention the sad and tragic change of director with Whedon stepping in to allow Snyder to grieve. I didn’t know of the moustache story which the new Deadpool trailer obviously snipes that. I was watching Cavill’s scenes with something bugging me about his face, especially his upper lip. It wasn’t until after the film that it transpired that Cavill was requested for reshoots but had already commenced filming for Mission: Impossible, whose studio refused to have Cavill remove his facial hair, so his tash and face fur was CGI erased. It’s not wholly terrible, but it’s certainly noticeable. I’m still not entirely sure of Batfleck, but I certainly don’t dislike him as much as I was expecting. Gadot is well and truly suited to her role though Momoa doesn’t quite suit Aquaman, even though he is a cool addition. There was enough Cyborg for me and he ended up feeling more like a filler as oppose to a key member of the team. The scenes he does have just reminded me of Battlestar Galattica! Flash’s parts were some of my favourites, especially towards the end of the film; and again, there must be a part of the DCEU that hates on Marvel for having Quicksilver do the best action sequences before them. Miller is perfect though I can’t help but think he’s the lovechild of Justin Long and Nathan Fillion! Now, one major criticism I have is the score, which doesn’t match, and even though Elfman recycle’s his own Batman theme from Tim Burton’s visualisation and uses noticeable snippets from John William’s Superman Theme; it sadly doesn’t suit the past films of DCEU. Elfman’s no stranger to superhero scores with Hellboy, Raimi’s Spider-Man and of course Burton’s Batman under his belt, but this was too dreamy and fantasy themed as opposed to Zimmer’s darker superhero style who’s currently retired from doing superhero scores. Junkie XL was first to fill the void who was then reported to being fired by Joss Whedon and replaced by Elfman; and whilst the sound mixing is brilliant, with the old themes echoing perfectly at the right times, it just doesn’t gel with the rest of the films at all, pushing this to be very different from the rest of the franchise. Overall, it’s a better edited film than Suicide Squad and a stronger continuation than Dawn of Justice; it’s actually a lot of fun but it doesn’t beat Wonder Woman and is actually quite a different film for the previous segments. Still not MCU calibre and it appears this franchise will forever be in their shadow; and sadly this hasn’t restored any of my faith in the DCEU. There's something to be said for low expectations. I went into this expecting the standard DC mess of destructive action and large plot holes. The result surprised me, not because it was good, but because it wasn't awful.

The plot had a bit of interesting act one setup, and a neat development in the second. It was the third act that was a bit light on plot, but the action sequences were not as chaotic or dour as previous films, and actually had some fun moments (how much of this was Snyder, and how much was Whedon is best left to your imagination). It was a bit strange to see some supporting cast members (Martha Kent, Alfred, the Amazons) that had laready been introduced, and some that had not (Cyborg's dad, Aquaman's crew).

There's mixed acting here. I'm still not sold on Ben Affleck's Batman. Gal Godot works better as a lead than a supporting character. Henry Cavill didn't really change anything. Ezra Miller was a breath of fresh air, and Jason Momoa added a surprising amount of nuance. Ray Fisher was fine.

If DC wants to up their game, they are moving in the right direction. The problem is, they appear to be moving...very...slowly...............

My main problem with this movie is the fact that this movie was made. I hate to compare Marvel to DC because I love both equally, but the reason why Marvel's Avengers is so successful is because we got to know most of the characters before the first Avengers movie. In Justice League, we do know Wonder Woman, Superman, and Batman relatively, however I think it would've been nice to get to see Cyborg, the Flash, and Aquaman in movies before Justice League. They don't have to have movies for themselves, but it would be nice to see them in movies with Wonder Woman, Superman, or Batman before Justice League. I believe Aquaman is actually getting his own movie however, my personal opinion is that it would've been nice for this movie to come out before Justice League. I think the reason why people have been more biased to Marvel is because they've created more of a universe than DC has. The way they have told the story and preparing for the first Avengers movie created excitement because the audience loved the previous movies and loved the characters. Whereas DC introduced us to Wonder Woman, Superman, and Batman before Justice League, however they didn't do quite as good of a job. Wonder Woman was an amazing movie, however, we can all agree Batman vs. Superman was kind of a flop. Justice League has a chance to become great, however, I don't know how they can fix this. It seems their main problem is that recently they've had movies that weren't as good. Like I said, Wonder Woman was amazing, but then there are movies like Batman vs. Superman and Suicide Squad. Batman vs. Superman was rushed and Suicide Squad was disappointing because, again, it was rushed, and the advertising was very misleading. Most of the trailers and even the movie pictures made it seem the Joker was the villain, but then it was Enchantress. Also, I honestly think they should've just given the Joker and Harley their own movie before Suicide Squad. Honestly, that would probably make way more box office money than Justice League got (which isn't saying much). Basically, I think DC hasn't take the time to tell their character's stories in better detail because they're just trying to keep up with Marvel. It just seems all of their movies lately (besides Wonder Woman) have been rushed, and that is why I didn't like them coming out with Justice League. Also, the storyline for DC doesn't flow as well as Marvel's.

The idea of a superhero crossover film was taboo twenty years ago. Everything was standalone and that's the way we liked it. Honestly, did we even really know that we wanted to see more than one comic book lead in a film back then. I don't remember myself, but once Marvel began spoon feeding us these tiny cameos in their after credits sequences that became films that had full fledged teams of superheroes it seems as though a hole that we had as movie audiences was filled. Everywhere we look now we get the news that some studio is planning a "cinematic universe" to create an entire slate of films and more importantly revenue.
The main competition on comic books news stands for Marvel has been DC for decades. Marvel has some iconic characters, but DC also has characters that have been a part of popular culture since the late 1930's. The thing is that the stars have never aligned to deliver a film featuring their own team called the Justice League, other than cartoons and an awful TV special back in the 1970's. They're now trying to play catch up with a definite hit or miss game plan as they enter their fourth film Justice League.
The film follows an intergalactic threat named Steppenwolf (voiced by Ciaran Hinds) whose objective is to find three cubes called Mother Boxes that will turn the Earth into his home world.  It's destroying to create, ala Genesis in the Star Trek II and III arc. This is a post Superman world and Batman (Ben Affleck) has decided to not be so homicidal and build a team to work together to battle evil across the globe. Wonder Woman (Gal Gadot), The Flash (Ezra Miller), Aquaman (Jason Momoa), and Cyborg (Ray Fisher) round out the Justice League as they prepare to battle the greatest threat to this world. 
The idea of a Justice League film would have gotten me excited ten years ago. Now, not as much as it should have mainly due to the poor delivery of films such as Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice (a marquee film that is a waste of stories and characters) and Suicide Squad (a film with a good concept, but no real antagonist). Wonder Woman bucked that trend with a film that is interesting and exciting, but there was still the feeling of dread when this newest DC film came to the local Cineplex. 
Even before an audience saw this film the troubled production left many without hope for how Justice League was going to turn out and the verdict is that it is nowhere near a perfect film, but it is a step in the right direction being better than BvS and SS. There isn't that dark despair that punctuated those two films and it feels more like a typical superhero film that actually takes a few beats and has some comic relief. One of my main complaints about Batman v. Superman is that there were no real breaks from the constant action and darkness of characters that were developed so many years ago. Justice League manages to get some laughs, breaking up the seriousness and tension of the film, mainly with Miller's timid portrayal of The Flash, and the general bad assery of Momoa's Aquaman. These characters are more like you would want, except for Wonder Woman who feels like she has been regulated to second fiddle in this film, a shame considering her solo film was such an exciting film.
What causes the problems with Justice League lie in the story. Once again we get Steppenwolf and his collection of video game sprites for our heroes to fight throughout the film, which is something that really polluted Suicide Squad. The character is better than Enchantress, but in the end it feels like you're fighting thousands of the same thing, which has become a well dulled cliché. Then there's the Superman (Henry Cavill) issue. We all knew he was going to come back in this film after being dispatched in Suicide Squad. Sadly, it really isn't very momentous and seems a bit too easy. I know characters come back in comic books all the time, but this really doesn't gel with the rest of the film. The plus is that when Superman does work out his issues, Cavill plays the character more like we are used to instead of the brooding character that was really cutting into Batman's psyche territory.
Justice League is a step in the right direction for the DC Extended Universe. It is an entertaining film that doesn't feel like a two and a half hour depression screening (thankfully they kept the running time at two hours). It is not close to a perfect film, but it does stand as a popcorn movie. I have had an appreciation of these characters for as long as I can remember, so they do hold a special place for me.  Hopefully they can keep going in the right direction as they move forward.

For all it's problems at least "Batman V Superman: Dawn of Justice" was tonally consistent. I don't necessarily think that it was better than "Justice League" (both are just OK)  but here you've got such an awkward combination of Snyder's very morbid pastiche style and Whedon's sarcastic and dopey Saturday morning cartoon writing that you wonder what the final product would be like if the movie had just picked a singular vision.

I'll start off by saying the cast here is excellent. They have phenomenal chemistry, and they feel genuinely like the Justice League whenever you see them together. There are amazing moments that created a sense of wonder for me, and it was a privilege to just see the League together. Fighting side by side. Unfortunately, the visuals, the story, and the arc with Superman that had been building being wasted... it wasn't what it could have been. I did have a good time with this movie because I love these characters, but that can't be the metric by which I judge this film.

DC Comics can't seem to find equal footing with Marvel. This movie doesn't help. Gal GODOT, and Jason Momoa were the strongest characters. The others seemd underdeveloped with Afleck being the worst of the bunch. Overall it is not a terrible diversion but I was expecting a much better movie.

While it isn't one of the best entries in the DCEU, it still manages to be a fun, lighthearted movie where you can sit back and eat your popcorn, although much of the plotpoints were kind of ridiculous.

Not even worth renting.  absolutely confusing in cinematic style.  it is not sure whether it wants to be a dark action thriller or cartoon based comic book movie.  It did't land either one. It seems like DC tried to land an ironman-eesque style, but landed closer to a george clooney-esqu batman.  the only interesting part was the flash.  not a fan of this movie at all, and I actually really liked Batm Vs Superman, Wonder Woman, and man of steel.

I am a hardcore DC fan. With the footage released prior to the full release, I was geeking out for months. Flash seemed less melodramatic and gloomy than his television counterpart, Aquaman looked like a badass king, Cyborg was a broken, angry young adult, Wonder Woman seemed to be as powerful as ever, and Batman seemed to be the alpha dog of the JL. Oh, Warner Brothers. You misled us with the excessive Leto-Joker promo before Suicide Squad, and look what that turned out to be. Justice League seemed to be a completely fine film before Snyder left the project out of grievance (his daughter took her own life). Joss Whedon, a usually credible director, likely undid all of the ups promised. Desperate reshoots to lighten the tone to seem more like an Avengers copycat, and we can't forget the now infamous Cavill-stache. I may come off as a Snyder fanboy, but I feel like there was no need to alter this film. Snyder had a clear vision on what he was going for. I'm not saying it was going to be amazing, but it would've turned out a tad better. Marvel fans argue that DCEU is just trying their hardest to catch up to MCU by whipping up anything that'll get people in the theater. That might be true, but some of the performances contradict such. Fisher's Cyborg was an angsty character, but for good reason. He was robbed of his future. Miller gave Barry Allen heart and humor. For the few Superman scenes, Henry Cavill was more like a true superhero than ever. Sadly, Wonder Woman felt like a watered-down version of her earlier portrayals. Aquaman was alright, but wasn't as intimidating. And oh boy, Batman and Steppenwolf were BAD. Batman was the highlight of the rather disliked Batman V Superman: Dawn of Justice. He felt taken straight out of the iconic Miller graphic novel "The Dark Knight Returns". This time, he felt like a not confident, wimpy departure from the almost moral-less predecessor. Steppenwolf followed the blatantly recycled superhero team-up villain formula: take over the world, for, reasons. This film really disappointed me as a huge fan of DC, on the screen and on the comic pages. 5/10
