Not the best movie but not as bad as the critics make it out to be.  It is easy to see where the movies are going and how they have improved.  Of course I am one that enjoyed the previous DC installments.  I am a DC fan and realize that their world is not as bright and bubbly as Marvel's.  Still some issues though, my biggest complaint was wasting Aquaman and Cyborg.  They felt like an afterthought.  I also took issue with the villian, he was neither bad nor good, just the standard CGI baddie who brought nothing to the film.  Superman was a better villain for the 3 minutes he was pissed off.  The stand out was Ezra Miller though, his take on the flash was great and his ability to land the comedy stuff was spot on.

This movie has lots of problems granted but the main charters were good (excluding cyborg). This movie tried to come back from such a letdown of Batman v Superman and for that I think it did well. The directing for this movie was not great with the directing you can tell which seen was done by who. However the mustache is unforgivably bad.

Justice League or part 3 of the new Superman movies wasn't bad.  Critics gave it 40% which is just wrong.  Granted, all these superhero movies and television shows are getting a little long in the tooth even for me a longtime fan of the genre.  Thanks to George Lucas and the advances at ILM with CGI we can finally recreate all the comic books of our youth in stunning visuals.  However we must remember what George warned us about, "CGI is great but you can't forget the story." Paraphrasing there.  
Back to the numbers, how is it that Wonder Woman got a 92% while Batman vs Superman Dawn of Justice only got a 27%?  Ok BVS wasn't a great story and it had many flaws in the telling.  I would even go so far as to say that only by watching the director's cut can you even follow the story at all.  Justice League has a very simple story line not unlike all the latest Marvel movies that critics keep fawning over.  75% for Avengers Age of Ultron? It's the same story!!  Something is wrong here.  Critics these days are far too politically correct.  Wonder Woman was good but it wasn't so much better than Justice League and again a 92%.  Why?  Because it's a woman superhero?  I have been a fan of Wonder Woman since the old TV show with Linda Carter but I can still look at it objectively.  Yes it was a good movie but it had its flaws and the story was not great.  It makes me wonder if Disney is paying critics under the table and because Warner Brothers can't afford the extortion payments they get dinged for their movies.
So let me discuss the overall story line here as one movie leads to the next.
Man of Steel:
First movie in the series where we get a fresh take on the superman back story.  The back story where they were still on Krypton was the best part of the movie and added something fresh.   Ultimately Superman grows up and then helps destroy the city where Batman lives in an attempt to rid the world of his fellow Kryptonions who have come to earth to take him away so they can use his DNA to rebuild their race.  Not sure why they didn't just go off and start a new family with the people on their ship and save themselves the trouble.   Superman kills!!!!!  Oh well.

Batman Vs Superman:
Is the continuation and shows how Bruce Wane is going to kill Superman for destroying the city but before he can do that the evil and crazy Lex Luther decides that he is going to create a monster to destroy everybody.  Batman and Superman, (Now friends because they both have a mother named Martha) team up to kill the monster.  Wonder Woman also arrives out of nowhere to help fight.  Sadly Superman dies in the last moments of the battle and the movie ends with dirt vibrating on the coffin.  
Justice League:
I really liked the intro of this Movie where Batman is on the roof defending his beloved Gotham.  Batman is by far my favorite DC hero.  He is human with lots of money and some detective skills who dresses like a bat and beats up the bad guys.  What's not to like for an 8 year old kid?  For this rendition, Ben Affleck dons the cowl and in my opinion is one of the better Batmans of my lifetime.  He does a good job of playing the older worn out man who is still trying to save his city, one bad guy at a time.    One critic mentioned that he looked as if he didn't care or didn't want to be there but I didn't see that at all.  There was just enough humor and action to make me believe.  The batman story was far better in Justice League than it was in Batman Vs superman.   
Overall the story goes like this.  3 large square boxes that hold great power. (Anybody else thinking Tesseract here?) are hidden throughout the world.  The moment Superman dies the mother stones begin to call out to the evil Stephen Wolf who has been away from earth for thousands of years.  He is the apocalyptic destroyer of worlds whose last attempt to destroy earth failed.  However now that Superman is dead he will easily get his revenge.  He has come to reunite the three boxes giving him the power he needs to send out huge purple worms to destroy the earth.  (Anybody thinking Ego from Guardians of the Galaxy2?)   
With the world at risk it's time to gather the team.  Bruce Wayne begins by running off to the frozen north to find Aquaman.    Best version of Aqaman I have ever seen by the way.  Not sure I understand his out of the water abilities and he can't talk to fish but good to know we have another strong arm on the team with a trident of power in his hands.
Flash is next with a quick back story thrown in to tell you that his dad is in prison for killing his mother and he is trying to prove his father's innocence?  I think I would have rather had this all be a mystery and had the flash be a little less nerdy.  The Flash in the cartoon version of the Justice League is a much cooler version than this one and if you can't do the back story justice why try?
Wonder Woman.  Ok she is the best part of the movie.  Still hot and powerful and because we had the Wonder Woman story we have some good background about what she can do.
Cyborg:  The back Story on Cyborg was the weakest part of the movie.  We got a glimpse of him in the Batman vs Superman movie but other than that they do a very poor job of explaining how one of the boxes gave him his abilities and what those abilities are.  Does he have limits?  He is a lot like the Iron Man of the group.
Not having enough power yet to take on Stephen Wolf, Batman comes up with a plan to bring Superman back to life by using one of the boxes of power.  It's a good thing that the Flash can control lightning to charge the box enough to open it so that some can come out and fall into the water of( ok I got confused here.)  Anyway Superman is blow back to life and is a zombie and after SuperZombie almost kills Batman Alfred rides in with Lois Lane to save the day.  SuperZombie will be ok now that Lois is here. But Superman flys away with her and we aren't sure if he is ever coming back.  As if.
Well we can't wait for Superman because Stephen Wolf just stole the last box and he is flying away to Russia to end the world.  
Ok so the movie is over at this point.  Without proper build up which we never got, we never believe that Stephen Wolf even has a chance.  We are just waiting for Superman to wake up and join the fight.
Oh and it turns out that Cyborg has so many abilities that just keep changing he will be able to save the day by plugging into the Mother stones, talk to them and somehow break them apart.  Nope he needs the help of Superman to do it.  
Overall the movie was entertaining.  I was able to stay awake which is saying something these days.
My previous points about back story is one of the biggest problems with Justice League and many stories these days.  The only real back stories we have for these versions of these heroes are Wonder Woman and Superman.   We have nothing for Aqaman, Flash or Cyborg and very little for this Batman so it doesn't matter how cool they are we don't know them and ultimately don't care about them.  They could have pulled a giant magic rabbit out of their costumes and destroyed Stephen Wolf with it and we would have had the same reaction to the ending of this movie that we did but it may have been funnier.  If you haven't been following the comics sadly you have no idea what these heroes are capable of.  Can they even be hurt when flash falls down does he bleed?
We knew from the start of the movie that there was no way that Stephen Wolf was going to destroy the world so you have to make the story good enough that you wonder if he might.
In this case the final battle was just the end of the movie rather than a big build up.  We are glad to say that the purple worm only got a few miles away from home base before it turned into pretty flowers. 
I waited for this movie to come out on Blue Ray because the reviews were so bad.  Sad that I let the critics influence me so much but these days it's hard to guess.  Perhaps the movie was better at home because I didn't have to listen to the crowd laughing at the sometimes stupid humor and that added some needed seriousness to it but overall the story wasn't any worse than so many other hero movies but the timing was wrong.  They should have done a flash movie a batman movie a cyborg movie and an Aquaman movie before bringing them together.   Then we would have had a great back story for everybody and this story would have had a lot more to it.  
Good overall acting except for Superman's CGI lips that needed to go back in for some more acting lessons.
Honestly I think we are just starting to grow tired of all these super hero movies with the same story being told over and over again.  Where is the real conflict that perhaps doesn't get resolved in 2 hours?    How many times can we watch one guy or Woman, pounding on another guy and not get tired of it?  
When I was 8 It could have gone on for a long time but I am not 8 and I need better.

This is the biggest cinematic disappointment of my 2018 thus far.  The movie opens to Superman being filmed by a couple of kids for their blog.  due to cavill's contract with another film he could not shave off his mustache for reshoots of justice league so they had to use cgi to remove the mustache.  the result is horror incarnate.  at first i thought it was a superman imposter then when i realized this was the actual superman i stared in disbelief, mouth agape.  i wondered out loud to my wife something about first impressions being everything as i tried my hardest to "the sphere (1998 - dustin hoffman, Samuel L. jackson, & sharon stone)" this crap and try to forget it.  ok, i forgive this.  contract stuff can be tough, lets just hang onto judgment and watch the rest of the movie.  well it only got worse from there.  i keep seeing complaints in the reviews i read about wonder women being ogled by the camera and i definitely agree that that happened but i would argue that this was the only thing that saved the movie.  My wife absolutely despised the flash.  when did the flash turn into an aspergers afflicted 14 year old?  (my son has aspergers so I have first hand experience).  i laughed at his jokes a few times but they didn't redeem the performance.  the worst part is that i was one of the few that really enjoyed dawn of justice.  I thought affleck could be a pretty dang good batman.  i still think he can be in fact but he was not that in this film.  what they did to batman here is inexcusable.  they made it to where i couldn't care less about batman.  this made my heart break.  i thought there was something wrong with me.  batman is one of the greatest comic characters of all time and they turned him into the madam at a house of disrepute.  the glasses on his bat suite made him look like a moron.  it was the worst looking bat vehicle i can imagine.  in bvs, affleck was awesome.  in my opinion he was the perfect bruce wayne then he follows it up with this crap?  the only truly good bruce wayne moment was at the very end of the movie.  also, we have seen dark and gritty all throughout this universe dc and warner bros have constructed and then halfway through this movie they wanted to make it a marvel movie.  lighthearted and fun and witty.  complete 180 degree switch from man of steel, bvs, and 80% of wonder woman.  make up your mind.  don't listen to the fans and what they want because we have no idea what we actually want (aside from a flashpoint paradox movie, we absolutely want that).  but fans are morons 90% of the time yet this movie feels like they based the entire thing of the comment section of 4chan.  the lego batman movie was miles better than this flaming pile of excrement.  my wife didn't even like the christian bale batman until she saw this movie.  now she wants bale and nolan back. keep in mind batman has always been one of my favorite characters.  i love dc and marvel.  i loved bvs, wonder woman, and man of steel so don't just dismiss me as a hater of all things dc because i'm not.  this movie was just that bad. steppenwolf was terrible.  its like this movie had a massive budget and spent it all on cocain and strippers.  the cgi was pitful.  you can clearly tell when there is a green screen behind them.

now for the positives:  wonder woman nails it yet again.  cyborg and the close ups of gal gadot's backside were the best part of the film until we got to see superman.  the fight between our heros was pretty awesome.  i give this part of the film a 10/10 and the entire reason why i rated it a half star.  I even enjoyed aquaman for the most part.  oh wait, did he just surf on a parademon?  Yeah that ruined it.  if you're going to be dark and brooding then be dark and brooding.  this movie felt like my teacher did when i would turn my homework in after doing it 5 minutes before class.  rushed.  agonizing.  terrible.  skip it.  i know you won't if you're a true dc fan but don't say i didn't warn you.

I'm a little disappointed(wholly in myself) for paying too much heed to the critics score and tomatometer here, and thus waited for this on disc.  
While the complaints given in poor reviews are somewhat(and in cases, mostly) valid (poor villains, thin characterization, "poor" CGI, etc.) the film still stands as one of the best in the full DC catalog, going all the way back decades.       
As seriously as I take my heroes(super and otherwise)  the critics are misguided in reviewing what is essentially a 7 DECADE old franchise in the same way as more serious fare.  Approach this film (and others like it) like a kid, and not like a Superfan or a Critic, and it's pretty good genre fare.  I'm a Marvel guy, for the most part, and I found this film MUCH better than Many of the films in the MEU that received better ratings.

I honestly thought that this movie was very poorly written and directed. The plot is very poorly planned out, skipping over major key points in order to build up to the story. They very briefly go over the back story of the main villain but barely skim the surface. This leaves the viewers wondering why this character is in the story and how he relates to the superheroes. This is very different than Marvel, who has spent years laying out the background and backstory to all their characters' lives. This movie pales in comparison, leading to a very fast plot with a villain that no one has ever heard of before. They spend  3/4 of the movies just trying to get the whole team together! This movie would've been a lot better if DC has waited until the background for each individual superhero to come out in their individual movies. Overall, not a very planned out movie, but has a possibility to build and improve on in the future.

The DCEU find themselves at a corner stone where they have fixed a lot of things while overdoing some things as well. The movie has a messy plot, the villain is weak, the CG looks awful, and the Whedon humor touch ups are hit or miss. However, its best moments come from its characters and their team building that felt interesting and newly realized (if you were sick of a certain Super character being a mope, you'll be relieved). It's messy but it's a lot better than I expected, even with my bar set very low. That being said, too many problems anchor this sinking franchise.

Problem 1 with Justice League. They tried really hard to put the origin stories of Cyborg, Flash, and Aqua Man inside a single 2 hour movie. To me it was just disorganized and confusing. Problem 2. And this is the conclusion since I only really had these 2 problems, but to me it's a big one, so I'll do it in all caps, because it bugs the crap out of me. YOU SPENT 300 MILLION DOLLARS ON A MOVIE BUT ONLY ABOUT 20 BUCKS TRYING TO FIX SUPERMAN'S MOUTH? Jeez Louise. I'm an amateur. But I feel like I could have done better with a flesh color Crayola crayon.

Justice League is a very underrated movie in the DCEU. Although the movie has its clear flaws, the standout characters and on screen appearance of the finest DC heroes make Justice League an enjoyable and worthwhile movie experience for anyone. The movie kicks in at just over two hours, and this is very noticeable as a lot of scenes are cut short and the transition is very choppy, especially in the first half. Warner Brothers should have let the movie have a much longer run time, as there is a lot to tell and show in this movie. There is also an obvious differentiation in the tone as well, as the movie did have two directors with different views, such as Josh Whedon's more colourful and lighter tone. Despite these noticeable and sometimes frustrating flaws, all the heroes are standouts and generate great chemistry with one another. They each have their individual moments, where we learn about who they are or where they are at in their development. This is where the run time can be a downfall, as we don't learn enough about Aquaman, the Flash, and Cyborg due to their stand-alone movies being scheduled for future releases. It would have been nicer to see some more of these characters origins. However, they all prove to be very likeable and relatable characters. Batman and Wonder Woman return as well, as they build on their arcs from previous DCEU films. The return of one character is also a major plus of the movie, and is finally the big screen adaptation many fans have been waiting for. The villain Steppenwolf is weak and fully CGI, and proves to be another disappointing villain in the superhero movie genre. The action makes up for many of these flaws however, particularly Steppenwolf's battle with the Amazons and the final battle with all the heroes coming together as a team. Overall, Justice League has it's obvious flaws, but they are easy to overlook with the amazing heroes and fun action sequences.

Justice League's fun cast and thrilling action pieces can't offset the film's clashing visions and dirty studio politics.

Ultimately, the origin stories, narrative threads, stylistic tones, even the graphics-nothing about Justice League quite comes together. The seams are definitely showing here, which is to be expected from a movie with trying to do so much. Introduce three new major superheroes? Don't expect them to be anything more than paper thin. Hire a second director to finish where the first left off? Don't expect a coherent tone. Recruit a team and save the world in under two hours? Don't expect to care about anyone or see them grow at all. Reshoot major swaths of the film after the actors have left the project and grown mustaches? Don't expect even the CGI to be able to save these heroes from this mess.

"Justice League" has the seeds for a great movie within it, but they're caged within a merely "good" film. Though the writing still fails his character (and ironically it shares a lot of similarities to Tony Stark's role in "Avengers: Age of Ultron"), Ben Affleck still comes off as a pretty solid Batman and he much more like the way I want the character to be. [However, I know it's a personal thing, but it's still weird seeing an interpretation of Batman, Miller-inspired or otherwise, using guns meant to hurt people and not just for rappelling up/down buildings; that's just me talking.] He is even better here than he was in "BvS." Another great thing, obviously due to her movie's success, is that Wonder Woman is given many of the best action scenes and lines in the flick. I was also pleased that this film finally delivered the kind of Superman I have wanted, and have been waiting, to see Henry Cavill play for two movies now (even if the method for the Man of Steel's resurrection seems almost more complicated than the comics' version). The filmmaking crew gave Aquaman (Jason Momoa) some nice opportunities to show off his cool powers, but outside of what the hardest of the hardcore DC fans know about him, general audiences have no real reason to care about this character or his backstory (later to be explored in his solo movie this December). Despite Ezra Miller's and the script writers' aims to turn Barry Allen into the CW "Flash" show's version of Cisco Ramon, he becomes something more akin to "The Big Bang Theory"'s Sheldon Cooper with all of his jittery behaviors and anti-social demeanor. Still, even with that and his powers feeling very reminiscent of the Quicksilver scenes from the most recent "X-Men" flicks (and again, not to mention the CW show), this Flash was cool to watch on the silver screen. On the other side of things, both the reverse-engineered message of "hope" (compared to "BvS"'s dourness) and Aquaman's second-act speech [that's designed to create team tension a la "The Avengers" as well as push the narrative forward] feel hollow and come off as cheap sentiments. When viewers finally get to the good action and thrilling teamwork at the end, the film decides it is time to wrap up all plot threads with a whimper. My biggest critiques of the film, though, come from the story, its tone, and the half-hearted, phoned-in stabs at humor that undermines the proceedings (making one feel like he/she was watching one of my least-favorite Marvel movies, such as "Guardians of the Galaxy" or "Ant Man"), as well as the suggestively-incomplete CGI for Cyborg (who fails to leave an impression) and Steppenwolf; I assume both of these problems are possibly symptomatic of a larger issue (re: easy-to-fix minor nits growing into bigger concerns for the film as sacrifices for the movie to meet its release-date deadline). I was also HIGHLY disappointed in Amy Adams' Lois Lane being placed in such a limited role that she might as well have been written out of the plot. Overall, the film is watchable and thrilling enough and far from the dumpster-fire that numerous critics have claimed it is, but DC kneecapping its own product keeps it from achieving true greatness.

It’s a fairly entertaining film - and I love superhero movies so I’m an easy audience - but the problem I have with the film is, well, what is the point of the Justice League? Spoiler alert!!!! At the end superman pretty much did everything, he beat the baddie, he saved civilians etc. The only character that had a fairly big input was cyborg who split the cubes (but then superman finished the job on that too). It’s annoying - Wonder Woman should be a real match for superman, but he beat her easily! He’s as fast as the Flash too. Let’s face it, he’s probably a pretty good swimmer. I think it would be far better if they had brought superman back earlier in the film, and each member of the league had an input in defeating the bad guy that superman absolutely couldn’t match. If he can match it - and beat it - then what’s the point of the league?? Oh - and as a last point, it was rubbish that he beat up batman so badly. The film played way too much on the fact batman doesn’t have powers. Yes, we know that. What makes him a great character though is he ALWAYS has great gadgets that make up for the lack of superhero strength. He should have had some to hand and put up a bit of a fight at least.

Okay- to start with, I absolutely loved MOS and BVS. I did my best not to read or see anything about those two movies going in, other than the occasional headlines about how critics hated them, so I had low expectations going in. I was very pleasantly surprised when I saw those two movies. When I saw the low reviews for this film, I assumed they were just a bunch of trolls who just hate everything Jack Snyder does, and I had high hopes. They were not wrong. This movie was bad. The "funny quips" are lame, the CGI villain looks terrible, and the story just had no flow to it. It's been a while since I've seen a movie where I was just hoping the next thing I would see would be the ending credits next. The Superman story-line seemed rushed, and wtf was up with Amy Adam's reaction to finding out her bf Supes was just resurrected from the dead? No surprise? No, "Holy sh*t, Commissioner Jonah Jameson! You really weren't lying when you picked me up, and said you had just brought my love interest back to life!" Nobody's emotions or reactions were lining up with what was going on around them, except maybe Cyborg- who spends half of his screen-time being moody about what was done to him. But after a while, maybe brush that chip off your shoulder and accept it? I'm also taking a beef at the extras in this story who were super annoying, beginning with the kids talking to Superman on the camcorder, but using cutesy toddler-talk that seemed to belong in a Pixar film and ending with the Russian family that simply did not belong in this film. If you want to see how by-standards should be filmed, check out the montages in MOS and BVS where Superman is rescuing people. They don't need ten minutes of film-time devoted to them so that we can see them cowering in fear, and we don't need their backstory. They are basically props- and your super-heroes (and Batflic) should always be the main focus. Even the burglar that Batflic runs into on the roof has dialogue that did not make sense. You get caught robbing a place, Batman kicks your butt, he then fights a flying insect man, it explodes, and then you're just going to casually make conversation with Batman like you two are best bros? The movie also throws out so many expositional dialogue dumps at you that you feel like you are watching the product child of the Lord of the Rings and DC Comics.  "Quick, light the ancient warning fire." Overall, this movie was just bad. I read, afterwards, that the directors were replaced and a good portion of the movie was reshot, and I also read that the movie studio wanted a lighter movie, so that may play a hand in it. There was even snippets of the old Batman and Superman music themes, which I see a lot of reviewers liked, but I found it distracting and further takes you out of the fantasy that the movie was trying to create. Keep going this route and you guys are going to lighten this movie to the point where you'll be in Batman and Robin or Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer territory. Just an overall tragedy. I think I'll wait and rent the next one instead of buying it on its first day of digital release.

So this was it, the main event, the big one to rival Marvels 'The Avengers'. Only five movies in and DC (along with Warner Bros.) felt it would be a shrewd decision to whack out their superhero team-up flick, hmmm.

This was always gonna be a hard sell with the performance of previous DC movies. Superman hadn't really set the world alight and the Suicide Squad was a nice idea that was badly executed. Wonder Woman of course did well (boosted by a political agenda) but that now seems like a flute more than anything. We hadn't had any stand alone movies for Flash, Cyborg or Aquaman up to this point, something that just felt totally wrong. So not only was this a sequel of sorts to the previous Superman, Batman and Wonder Woman offerings, it was also a slight origins kick off for Cyborg, Flash and Aquaman (despite previous cameos).

Alas the plot is anything but fresh (its a superhero flick). A long long long long time ago on Earth, the evil supervillain Steppenwolf (stupid name) tried to take over the planet using three gizmos called Mother Boxes. He was beaten back by a whole team of other superhero types and said Boxes were hidden on Earth (if you wanna protect Earth, why not hide them elsewhere? Like in the far flung reaches of the universe). Much later in the present day the Boxes are triggered by the death of Superman? Or the presence of Superman? Are these things sentient beings? I have no friggin' clue but they activate and this gets Steppenwolf's attention. So he comes back to find the Boxes and try to take over the Earth to please his master Darkseid. Why he didn't just do this before I dunno, don't delve too deeply into this plot.

Enter our team of heroes, the Justice League. First up its good old Batman (Ben Affleck), the leader who's super power is being very rich (his own words). Alas this comment really hits home because his presence is really kinda stupid. Why would you need a regular human dressed in bat armour in a fight with super powered aliens and metahumans? He provides them with some cool vehicles...which they don't need, umm...he also lets them kip at his place? Unfortunately Affleck also seemed to not care about this movie seeing as he clearly didn't wanna be there, and he looked tubby. When he takes off his batsuit the shirt he has on underneath also has a muscle structure built into it. Methinks they had to cover his actual physique.

Then we have Supes (Henry Cavill) who is basically the same as before. Wonder Woman (Gal Gadot) who essentially struts around making smartass comments all the time. Apparently the success of Gadot's only movie has gone to her head because my God does she act smug for the whole time. The Flash (Erza Miller) is the obligatory comic relief which is enjoyable for what its worth but is at odds with the movies tone. Also where did he get that Nasa material to build his suit? Next up is Cyborg (Ray Fisher) who is another character that doesn't really fit here. Like what does this guy do? He's basically an agile Terminator, but it seems like he could be easily destroyed at any point. And lastly there is Aquaman (Jason Momoa), the final pointless character here unless you're fighting underwater. But wait, Aquaman seems to have powers on land in this movie too because plot necessities.

One problem I had with this movie were the effects and general look of everything. Firstly its that same old drab, metallic, dark, shadowy atmosphere that DC (via Zack Snyder) has been pushing this whole time. The movie looks awful, the colour palette is terrible, and it all looks the same. Naturally there is abundance of CGI which is to be expected but again its poor and obvious looking, whilst having that strange DC/WB videogame-esque look to it. Did I mention the greenscreen? Oh my God it was horrendous and so very very obvious. The battle between Steppenwolf's army and the Earth defenders at the start was horribly dated looking. Almost all underwater sequences looked bad plus you couldn't really make much out. Steppenwolf himself looked like a character out of a [i]Mortal Kombat[/i] movie. And Cyborg was quite jokey looking at times, he looked like he was made out of tinfoil with a bad face job.

I think the epitome of dross in this movie came when Aquaman surfed on a parademon whilst falling from a great height. He then crashes into a high-rise building, smashes all the way through it from top to bottom, and comes out surfing at the bottom with a grin on his face. This was literally cringeworthy cartoon garbage that also looked shit.

The other main problem here was the entire movie simply being cheap. As in using dated tropes and cliches whilst being just plain stupid. Thing is this was somewhat expected with the characters you're dealing with. Aquaman, he's useless, he merely pops up to do stuff that involves water because he's the water guy. Oh everyone's about to be drowned by a huge tidal wave!! Enter Aquaman...hurray! Oh we need someone to hack into this computer control panel thingy and do some hi-tech computer type stuff? Enter Cyborg because he's the robot guy. Oh we need someone to get somewhere really quickly or rescue some people in the nick of time? Enter Flash because he's the fast guy. Batman turns up to every battle in some yuge mechanical battle vehicle (because otherwise he's useless)...and it gets wrecked instantly. Batman loses a lot of gear in this flick. Wonder Woman strolls out of every battle without even her lipstick being smudged, ugh!

The acting was pretty dreadful across the board (except for Gal Gadot of course, because you can't say anything negative about her now). As said Affleck was clearly uninterested, Fisher swaggered as much as he could but was still awful, Momoa had big muscles and lots of hair, whilst the character of Steppenwolf was basically a live action pantomime. Of course there were numerous other characters throughout offering other actors a crack but its all cameo stuff really. A too many cooks situation basically, heck whilst the big finale battle was going down humanity was represented by one small family, probably because they literally couldn't fit anymore people in.

All in all I really struggled to find anything positive in this movie. The small sequence where the team brings Supes back from the dead was quite enjoyable. It was fun watching Superman knock the team around; I especially liked the eerie moment Supes spies Flash whilst he's zooming in his superhuman speed zone. Although, I'm not really sure why Supes would fight the team after his resurrection. OK he's understandably disorientated but why does he see the others as threats? The opening Batman sequence was also nice and harked back to earlier Batman movies in tone and visuals. Twas also lovely to hear a very short burst of Danny Elfman's Batman 89 score in one scene. It was literally a few seconds but even that was enough to really swell the scene in terms of awesomeness and nostalgia.

That's virtually it! That's pretty much the only bits in the movie that I genuinely liked. The rest of this effort felt very much like (ironically) a Joel Schumacher movie. Yes it is indeed that bad. The entire movie generally looks poor, the effects are very suspect at times (Cyborg), the greenscreen is some of the worst I've seen for some time, and the plot is generic as fuck. Add to that the even more generic villain Steppenwolf with his hordes of flying goggle wearing goblins, and a finale that was possibly the biggest anticlimax in years (considering the content we're dealing with here). And even now I still can't help but think Superman could of done this all on his own. Why is Batman, Wonder Woman, Cyborg and Aquaman even here?? Flash was probably the only other genuinely useful person. This really felt like bad a movie from the mid 90's. The bottom line, its ugly, dull and unbelievably uninspired.

I am writing this for 2 reasons. 1. I enjoyed this movie for the fun and wild ride that it is!! Pick up a comic people!! This flows just like a comic storyline would! (In fact, read the Justice League New 52, there are a ton of similarities to this movie). And 2. To say that rotten tomatoes is a garbage site. You are sucking on the nut sack of anything that has Marvel connected but then take DC movies that are of equal or better quality and shred them to pieces over the most obscure things. You aren't critics. You're trend followers. You don't have any self created thoughts in your heads, just take what you think people want and say it. This movie is just as good if not better than the first Avengers (which also had a huge amount of plot holes and continuity issues) but you all can't accept that someone else can make a hero film that doesn't follow the Marvel mold.

The story was ridiculous, the script was TERRIBLE, the effects were cheap, the humor wasn't funny, the villain was stale and astoundingly fake-looking, the characters were obnoxious and completely uninteresting, the direction was insane, the tone was deaf AND insane, the plot made no sense, Henry Cavill couldn't be bothered to shave for his re-shoots, Batman was flipped from a dark, dramatic character into a hacky early '90s comedian, The Flash was the most aggravatingly unamusing comic relief in superhero history. . . . I could go on, but what's the point? Even though this thing bombed harder than World War II, I guess it reached the right fanboy people who were already guaranteed to love it anyway. It's how a non-movie like "Suicide Squad" still managed to draw unwitting DC fans. It's just pathetic when compared to Marvel's amazingly consistent popular and critical successes. DC doesn't know what it's doing. Literally. Just look at what they did to their best hero here: Batman, the dark knight, made a completely uncharacteristic one-liner or quip in every other scene he was in. This, despite how he came off in the other films in this doomed franchise. They obviously don't care about their audience, so why should their audience care about them? Just a really, very bad movie, and a total humiliation when compared to the rock-solid competition. Marvel Studios couldn't make a flop if they tried right now. They're on one of the most unbelievable hot streaks in the history of popular entertainment. That'll end, as all things do, but they'll leave a legacy of at least a dozen great blockbuster movies in a row. And they just keep going. As I write this rambling, incoherent review, that new one they've got coming out-"Black Panther?" It's getting some of the strongest reviews for a superhero movie ever. It must be a sorry, humbling time for DC fans. I'm sorry, guys. I don't know what's wrong with the filmmakers either. It's a humiliatingly uneven playing field. DC can't reach the shoelaces of its rival, who just make much better and more popular movies than they do. Maybe one day that'll change, and some effort or intelligence will come in. I hope it will. Nobody WANTS to hate a film. I have to believe that. Maybe next time. Sorry DC fanboys. It's rough, I know.

My LATE, LATE, Justice League Review (SPOLIER-FREE) 

PROS:
1. The character designs were good (ONLY when it came to the heroes) Not mind-blowing but not bad either.
2. Compared to Suicide Squad, it's a LOT better in regards to being watchable.
3. It does end.

CONS:
1. The villain and his design were bloody atrocious. I'm sorry but if I can't remember his name HALF-WAY while I'm watching the movie and his design looks as if the ugliest monster you can think of from Dark Souls and Diablo had a baby and then turned the graphics down to PS1 quality (even saying it's PS1 quality   is generous), then you know you have screwed up.
2. The CGI made me feel almost physically sick. This movie makes Wonder Woman's CGI look comparable to the CGI in the Planet Of The Ape Reboot Trilogy. This movie makes the Scorpion King in the Mummy 2 look photo-realistic. OH, I am NOT taking that back.
3. The tone of this movie is really, really bad. DC was trying so hard to be like marvel that in the end, it made Justice League look hilarious, in all the wrong ways. Suppressing laughter throughout the serious parts of this movie was almost impossible for me. Jokes didn't fall flat on their face in this movie because they did land... on a floor of razor sharp spikes.
4. Aquaman and Flash are as funny as the live action Smurfs movie. If you haven't seen the live action Smurfs, don't.
5. Superman can be better portrayed by a rock with an S carved into it. 
6. "S" doesn't stand for "Hope". But I know one word it stands for which best describes this movie.
7. Although it's only 2 hours, it felt like more. A LOT MORE.
8. Every character in this movie (whether good or bad) has extremely unlikeable and unrealistic behaviour. 
9. The story, the acting and the dialogue is so bad that a poorly-written fanfiction would have more to offer.
10. I can probably come up with more but these are the ones that came on top of my head and we would be here for a while if I tried to list every last thing wrong with this movie.

IN CONCLUSION:
DC's extended universe, in my eyes, has failed exponentially. Each movie get's worse and worse. Currently, there are 5 DCEU movies. 1 of which is actually good (Wonder Woman), 1 of which is OK but not brilliant(Man Of Steel) and then you have BvS, you have Suicide Squad and then you have this. DC needs to cancel the DCEU. I'm not saying they need to stop making movies entirely, what I'm saying is that they need to try going in the direction they went with before with the Dark Knight. Focus on making a good movie that can stand out on its own rather than a movie that is only there to reference and fore-shadow later movies. Hell, Wonder Woman proved they can do this really well so just go in that direction. If they take this route, it can lead to a brighter future for DC.

While there is finally some humor in the DC movie universe, the film suffers from the same problems  that dragged the mediocre BvS down: The villain is a poorly animated CGI being that entirely kills any involvement in the story. You still come along for the characters, most of which are well portrayed. Especially Aquaman has some pretty good scenes and makes you hopeful for his coming own adventure. The story is neither particularly coherent nor interesting and Supie's return kinda meh. The showdown, once again, happens in an entirely fake CGI environment with the same fighting moves over and over. The result is still entertaining enough and sometimes even fun thanks to the actors, but one can't possibly say that this bunch of heroes doesn't deserve better films.

I personally think the movie was really fun. The action scenes were great, well choreographed, the character chemistry was fantastic. The cast were amazing, hands down. That said, the run time definitely should have been half an hour longer. The CGI felt unfinished in certain scenes, and the villain was lacking. The given villain motivation was vague, especially for non comic book readers. That said, I really had a fun time in the theater.

This movie could have been SOOO much better had Zack Snyder had been able to finish what he started. Many of the scenes that he directed (and were subsequently removed once Joss stepped in) fixed many of the pacing, worldbuilding and development issues that plagued his previous film. But when Joss stepped in for post-production, this movie was more of the same pile of garbage that other DCEU films (specifically BvS and Suicide Squad) churned out. Underdeveloped characters, a plot that is inconsistent, muddled and all over the place and a villain who is like Fan4stic's Doctor Doom-levels of bad but better by a slight margin. But nevertheless, I ultimately have to commend that this film showed Synder learning from his mistakes and improving on his mishaps, provided that the studio had not stepped in and ruined EVERYTHING. Action scenes were good though.

After years of anticipation, DC's answer to The Avengers has arrived.  It's been a rough road for DC, with all but one of the movies being either panned by critics, or receiving mixed reviews.  After a complicated production process, the final product is quite the mixed bag.  First, the good.  The league works well together, and they all develop quite well.  Batman and Aquaman learn to work in a group, Wonder Woman is still the strong leader she was, and the Flash is a good comic relief.  That chemistry between the group is vital, as the movie could not possibly be good in the slightest without it.  And, to the movie's credit, they handle this quite well.  The Flash was surprising, and the movie managed to give him a backstory and character development.  Aquaman looked and fought cool, but wasn't as interesting a character as he could have been.  Batman was much better in this movie than he was in BvS, and they at least tried to redeem him from his portrayal in BvS.  If you think he's going to be as good as he was in the Nolan trilogy, don't.  Jeremy Irons is also a great Alfred.  Wonder Woman may not be as good as she was in her solo movie, but the way she and the Amazons connect to the overall story is very interesting.  And, the bad.  Steppenwolf was one lame villain.  He's remarkably generic, seeking the Mother Boxes to destroy the world.  And the fight scenes with him, Aquaman, and Wonder Woman appear to be recycled.  His lack of clear motivation is also a problem.  Yes, there is apparently a deleted scene with Darkseid in it, but that really should have been in it to begin with.  Even if it's exactly like the Thanos scene in The Avengers, it would have made the movie as a whole better than if they dropped it.  Cyborg is all edgy and brooding.  While that is understandable, given his situation, it just feels like the same crap we saw in the previous DCEU movies.  Still, his presence here also means we'll probably never see a proper Teen Titans movie.  Superman's return, even ignoring its predictability, was extremely cringeworthy.  Also, it teases Green Lantern, but he doesn't appear outside of flashbacks.  That's not cool.  Given the internal issues there were at DC, you can pick this movie apart and see "the Zack Snyder parts" and "the Joss Whedon parts."  It's quite evident who would have done it better.  The future of the DCEU has been questioned lately, as Justice League didn't do nearly as expected at the box office.  DC absolutely needs to turn things around in their next few films if they want this franchise to be successful.

Let's be fair here people: the DCEU has it's problems. This movie is by no means as good as other DC films such as Batman (1989) or more recently Wonder Woman (2017), but it certainly isn't as forgettable and unlogical as Suicide Squad or BvS ("Save Martha" still makes me mad). 

The movie is at it strongest when the league is united, at least to me. The interaction between the members provides light hearted humor Aquaman being central to this (as evident to the wonderfull scene in which he sits on Wonder Womans lasso of truth). Without this, the thin plot would not be able to hold up.   

The CGI of Henry Cavills mustache certainly is laughably if not downright embarrassing. Steppenwolf, played by Ciaran Hinds, has to be the weakest characterof this movi,e if not in the entire DCEU, which is saying something (I'm looking at Jesse Eisenberg in BvS).

The DCEU may have taken a step back with this one, but it still has hope for progress in the near future. Can't wait to december.

Four movies have led to this.  So Steppenwolf (Ciarán Hinds) is coming to Earth.  He aims to obtain three mysterious mother boxes for power and domination.  It is too much for just one hero, so a team must be assembled to protect the world.  A league, if you will.  I have not been shy about how I have felt about DC on the whole.  I think they've been rushing into things with out fully realizing core concepts, and their movies, for the most part, have suffered for it.  You can't really blame them, as they've been trying to catch up to Marvel for about half a decade now, and their luck appears to finally be turning around, especially after the critical and financial success of Wonder Woman.  Make no mistake: Justice League has its fair share of problems, and I am sure I could nitpick this movie to death.  That said, the things I like about this, I really like, and I had a good time watching this, which is more I can say about Batman v Superman.  The biggest improvement in this came from a tragedy.  DC brought in veteran director Joss Whedon to step in and help out when Zack Snyder had to step away to be with his family for personal reasons (plenty of other sites have covered this, I'm not going to go into details for the sake of flow for this review).  This isn't Whedon's first rodeo; he directed The Avengers, and he knows how to do exactly what DC so desperately wants to accomplish.  Whedon's touches really shine through in the form of punch up dialogue, and there are actually fun moments to this, which is something that can't be said for Snyder's other DC offerings.  A lot of this also comes from Ezra Miller as the Flash.  He's extremely excited to be a superhero both as a character and as an actor, and it really helps the audience by serving as a connection point.  He also geeks out just being in the presence of other superheroes, which makes for a nice mirthful touch.  All of the new characters work well together (I'm including Wonder Woman in this camp as well), and then it kind of hit me: I want to see a Justice League movie without Batman and Superman, even though they aren't bad here.  I mean really, they make the stories feel so drab and overly serious, don't you think it would be an improvement at this point?  Like I said, there are loads of problems otherwise.  The villain is probably the most generic one in the universe if not in superhero movies in general, and his hive underlings are just cannon fodder for action sequences.  You don't care about the origin stories of the new people because they are so glossed over; they should have had their own introduction movie to get you invested, but that is neither here nor there at this point.  Also, a lot of the tension in the first half of this is undercut by the fact that you know where this is going to end up; you know these guys are all going to wind up fighting along side each other, why not just cut to the chase?  Still, the visuals look pretty good for the most part when it isn't too heavy on the CGI, and the chemistry is there.  There is a big question that DC needs to field: where do they go next?  I personally think they should pull back instead of going bigger and make smaller movies.  It would be paving the road for success in the future.

Which can be enjoyable but amounts to nothing more than forgettable.

DC doesn't seem to know what they are doing with their movies. First hour of the movie has a few bits of action, but just completely turned me off from the movie. And not sure what it is about this guy playing Flash, but I just do not like him.

After the enjoyable Wonder Woman I was hoping that the DCEU had turned a corner and that it was finally going to prove to be worthy competition for the MCU. Unfortunately that hasn't proven to be the case.

Starting with the positives (of which there are few), Gal Gadot continues to be decent in the role of Wonder Woman whilst Jason Mamoa shows promise as Aquaman (although he is underused). There are also a couple of good action sequences, those being Steppenwolf's attack on the Amazon's and the mid-film fight between Steppenwolf and the League.

As for the negatives, Ben Affleck goes through the film looking like he wants to be doing something else, Ezra Miller makes for an irritating Flash and Ray Fisher is rather dull and wooden as Cyborg, a character who feels like he's only there to make up the numbers. Amy Adams continues to feel badly miscast as Lois Lane and lacks any chemistry with Henry Cavill who continues to give a rather deadpan version of Superman. Steppenwolf also makes for an incredibly bad villain. There's absolutely no development given to his character so instead of feeling like a genuine threat to the planet, he just becomes another throwaway villain of the week, a problem that has been present in all recent DC films with the exception of Man of Steel.

The plot is as basic as you can get, and on top of that, incredibly dumb. It centres around Steppenwolf trying to collect three Motherboxes in order to be able to transform the earth into a replica of his homeland. If this was a standard superhero origin film than I could probably put something as unimaginative as this but for a film that should be the DCEU's biggest event to date, I expect an awful lot more. And I certainly don't expect to see something as dumb as the League leaving the Motherbox that they had just collected totally unguarded for Steppenwolf to beam down and collect. It's writing at it's most stupid and it's hard to believe that this could make it into such a big film. That is the worst offending moment, but along with the dreadful attempts at comedy, there are several moments that will just leave you with your head in hand in disbelief at the sheer stupidity of the film.

Finally, we have the CGI. Much has been made of the dreadful efforts made at removing Henry Cavill's moustache and it is fair to say that it looks laughably bad. Sadly that isn't the only poor use of CGI throughout this film. Cyborg looks awful and really stands out as being GI heavy, as does Steppenwolf. All of the action sequences are also littered with shoddy effects, most notably the final sequence which keeps up the DCEU's trend of having a final battle that is nothing more than a poorly orchestrated CGI mess. It's shocking to think that a film that cost $300m looks this bad.

Justice League is marginally better than Batman V Superman and Suicide Squad but it's still an awful film. If Warner Bros want the DCEU to survive then they really need to go away and have a look at who they are employing to write and direct their films as Wonder Woman aside, it just hasn't been acceptable so far.

DC's biggest superheroes unite for the action-packed adventure Justice League.  In the wake of Superman's death an alien warlord named Steppenwolf makes a play to conquer Earth by uniting three Mother Boxes that will give him ultimate power, but when Bruce Wayne and Diana Prince learn of Steppenwolf's plan they attempt to form a team of super-powered individuals, including the Flash, Aquaman, and Cyborg, to defeat him.  The introduction of the new Justice League characters is fairly well-done and opens the door to start exploring more of the DC Universe.  And all of the actors give pretty solid performances; except for Ezra Miller, who doesn't seem to have a handle on his character (Barry Allen/Flash).  Also, the CGI work is a bit weak and can be distracting at time. 
 Still, the action sequences are incredibly exciting and dynamic.  Entertaining and fun, Justice League is just what's needed to launch the DC Extended Universe to the next level.
